7
This movie is based on the resilience of a guy whom had the chance to
be all along his detention in the same cell, near the outer wall of the
prison. Then, of course, no one thought that a wall made of mud, which
conveniently doesn't make a sound when dug, wouldn't be sufficient to
prevent a detainee, who has nothing else to do, to dig it in to get
out.The rest of the movie is stepping up to be the masterpiece we all know
and love. But this, I can't call it a flaw, but these unlikely premises
really bugged me watching it. I still call it a good movie. But for it
to be THE best film, on this site, is pretty far-fetched.

******
23 November 2013
10
This movie is based on a novella by Stephen King, but don't let that
put you off. It's not a horror film, rather a thumping good ode to
friendship, hope, wit, wiles and wisdom, brimming with crackling
characters and topped with the most twister of twists since The Crying
Game. Found guilty of killing his unfaithful wife and her lover in a
fit of passion, sullen accountant Andy Dufresne (Robbins, casting off
his goof ball image to display more layers than the proverbial onion)
is shipped to the Gothic wind-swept corridors of the Shawshank State
Prison for life. It is here the movie gracefully unfolds. With a
beautifully rounded script, writer/director Darabont conjures up a
spellbinding personal odyssey stretching through the years from 1946 to
1967.

Shawshank Redemption is a great film, its actually one my favorites.
The characters are portrayed very well, except for Andy. I know he is

so...Either way the film shows cinematic genius and truly amazing story
telling. I enjoyed every second of it, some say certain areas of the
story dragged on too long but hey its prison. Every moment in prison is
dragged along. But I don't know about being the greatest film on IMDb.
I would say Citizen Kane should be number 1. Citizen Kane is so amazing
its actually art. So again loved Shawshank Redemption and I wish more
movies were like it, but I don't know about greatest film of all time.

******
19 July 2013
8
It has long been my contention that it is the movie-maker's task to
hold the viewer's attention, not to burden him with his self-indulgent,
difficult-to-follow symbolisms. That having been said, I find it
difficult to find another movie I would recommend more highly than The
Shawshank Redemption. Without any high- adrenaline action sequences or
steamy sex scenes (two sure-fire ways to get the viewer's attention),
this film somehow has the power to make you sit through all 142 minutes
without for a moment getting bored. And I challenge anyone who has seen
it to delete any scene, even any minute, from the final edit. The fact
is, you can't. Because every single scene is an essential element that
contributes to the final result: a masterpiece that captures the drama
of enduring friendship and resiliency of the human spirit more
powerfully than any other film ever made. Even those who normally do
not watch movies with a critical eye will find themselves so drawn into
this experience. I really can't say enough about this film. Suffice it
to say that this is certainly the Greatest Movie Not to Win an Oscar.
(Since Citizen Kane, at least. )Actually, I can forgive the Film Academy for not honoring this film
with the Oscars I firmly believe it deserved. But when the American
Film Institute in 1998 put together their list of The 100 Greatest
Movies of all time (covering the period from 1896-1996), and so
myopically overlooked Shawshank in favor of such titles as Rocky, Dr.
Strangelove, Network, and Jaws, well, I thought that was absolutely
ridiculous.I wouldn't hesitate to put it in the top five of all time.

convicted of murdering his wife and her lover and is sentenced to life
in Shawnshank prison where he meets a former crook named Reed played by
the brilliant actor of our generation Morgan Freeman. The two become
inseparable as they deal with prison life and the guards betting the
HELL out of some of the prisoners; one got killed to death by the guard
while the other hanged himself to death.Everyday they have to dig up
holes and eating disgusting food, but will Andy(aka Robbins)ever get
out of prison and did he really kill his wife and her lover in
cold-blood?Bottom line is this; I'm 22 years of age a female who hates watching
these kind of movies as there really not my cup of tea,I'm sort of a
romantic/fantasy/cartoon/drama/weepie kind of chick and I hate watching
violent movies,but this movie was really good;but seriously is it the

In my opinion this movie is far from the greatest movie of all time.
Thou, it's a thrilling story, includes great acting and visually
constitutes of some extraordinary cinematography. The overall
impression you're left with after watching the shawshank redemption
does not make a lasting one. I don't know if it's the relatively dull
undertone or the mainstreamness of its story style, which makes it a
rather ordinary movie experience. I believe the Godfather was a better
choice for the number one spot, however there are a lot of other great
ones out there. I don't regret watching this movie, it's well worth its 2,5 hours and I
recommend you to watch it for the movie classic it is. But I wont
bother to see it again.

1 May 2013
7
Never has perseverance played such a strong character on film. The
respect and friendship that came from it were against all odds, but to
do so one would need hope. Tim Robbins' Andy Dufresne manages that
intangible saving grace over decades while falsely imprisoned and it's
Morgan Freemans' Red who narrates for us and in constant perspective
against the institutionalization of the Maine State penitentiary. The
symbiotic relationship between the two is perfect cinema chemistry. The
ending is quite fantasy, but makes for good afternoon drama on TNT who,
I believe bought the rights for a cheep price, and that's a happy
ending for Ted Turner!

20 January 2013
7
It's a good movie. I love this film. It's a story about hope and dreams
and one whose emotional impact is as great as the Pacific Ocean is
blue. An amazing movie. Easily one of the best movies made during the
90s and definitely one of the top 'prison' movies of all-time. Pretty
much everything about this movie works and works extremely well! I have
not read Stephen King's novella (his first non-horror), but some of the
movie's deficiencies, such as the old-fashioned morality tale and
portentous message about camaraderie and redemption--must have been in
the source material. Darabont explores the range of human kindness and
cruelty as he lovingly and patiently sculpts his large cast of
characters against magnificent scenery.

******
5 March 2012
8
Essentially, The Shawshank Redemption is about the survival of the
human spirit---in a colossally adverse situation. The brutality and
corruption which goes on in Shawshank Prison...never hits the viewer
right between the eyes (like it should). Thats due to the calming tones
of our narrator...Morgan Freeman. Mans in-humanity to man....is on full
display here...and its this strange mix of violence, upright stoicism
and high morality that makes for a heady brew. Lets not under-rate the
narration of Morgan Freeman---this was a huge reason why this movie is
now considered to be...a Classic. So, why did it bomb when it was
released ? Maybe it needs a couple of viewings for all the gears to
mesh (Who knows?) My major criticism , is that i thought the two leads
needed to be a bit more edgy , a little bit more angry. After all
..they weren't Saints. However, the messages that most people take from
this movie are positive (me included). I do not think its a
Classic------but it sure is a powerful movie ... and a very good one.

******
10 February 2012
8
Having not read the book initially, this movie blew me away. With such
intricacy to detail and screenplay which kept the viewer gripped The
Shawshank Redemption was one movie which ranks as most appealing to me.The whole time I, as a viewer, did not expect that the ending was going
to be like that, to that extent. The acting was indeed superb and the
way of expressing the changes in character and settings was impeccable.To reiterate to an audience what was occurring inside of the jail, and
to depict changes in emotions and feeling with such clarity definitely
justifies that the director of this movie was more than the average one
in Hollywood.1994, 18 years ago, was when this movie was made but to the level to
which it takes one is truly outstanding. One is absorbed by it, and
there is no confusion about what is happening but rather thoughts in
the viewers' minds about "What is gonna happen next?" These thoughts
are present when watching a horror/ thriller movie for the most part,
but for aficionados of different genres to all like this movie proves
that this was one heck of a movie.Cannot miss this movie; it is one that makes one think, learn, and be
entertained simultaneously.

******
20 November 2011
5
Two imprisoned men bond over a number of years, finding solace and
eventual redemption through acts of common decency.With The Shawshank Redemption number 1 on the top 250, you can easily
say that I had huge expectations. I never thought of it as the best
movie ever, but I still thought it would a great, moving experience
that gradually deserved it's position. If your expecting just that; I
suggest to throw your expectations away and keep away. HONESTLY, I
found the film to be quite good but the movie is obviously overrated.
First up, the acting and directing was fantastic. The first, say, 30
minutes had drawn me in fantastically. Unforgivably, this is the point
where the movie dragged itself down and made me lose interest a couple
times. Again, this is no way means I hated the film; I found it to be
great, but the fact that this film is top (especially over The
Godfather) confuses me. Honestly, the final minutes failed to move me;
which I expected. But although I found the movie to be good, I don't
find it to be one of the best. In fact, I might forget about it soon
down the road. So if your like me, and had all these expectations for a
great film, and was sadly letdown by a poor interest-level, stay away.
I know I'm probably going to get a lot of heat for this post, but I'm
stating my opinion. Maybe I was too tired to understand the impact or
maybe I wasn't in the mood for this kind of film. MAYBE, one day, I'll
have the time to re-watch and reconsider my opinion. Nonetheless, I
wasn't too impressed. The movie is great but lacks your interest. I
gets 7/10 for it's premise and 5/10 for it's overrated score. I would
recommend (possibly) if your into prison movies and maybe not so much
if you relate to me. 5/10.

16 September 2011
7
I, like most of the people I have known in the past thirty years or so
that discuss movies find that some stick out as gems. This is not one.
Since this movie came out, no one of dozens of people that are my
friends have described it as the best movie ever. In terms of its rank
on IMDb, is TSR overrated? YES! I went to about twenty other movie
sites before I stopped looking and only found it on only one site
within the top twenty. Just try it yourself. You won't even find it in
the top fifty on most. Better than "The Godfather", no. Better than
"Citizen Kane", maybe - (another overrated movie). Se7en is a more
engaging movie in terms of relationships between people. Shawshank
Redemption is like a vanilla R rated Disney movie, but enjoyable
nonetheless. I don't dislike the movie. I just do not understand the
complex and secret algorithms that IMDb uses. On some pages IMDb claims
to explain its vote calculation methods to you and on others it says
that it will never disclose its method of calculation completely. Maybe
they have a system that works but is not perfect. It certainly does not
coincide with the number of people that have seen a particular movie.
Maybe the compensation for the fact that far fewer people have seen TSR
than The Godfather is a factor.

14 August 2011
10
Wow, been a few years. I'm editing my old post. I'd like to humbly
thank everyone here for rating my flick so highly. #1, huh? Providing
the story for Shawshank Redemption was an imagination of myself under
the short story's circumstances. It is similar to K-PAX that way and of
the same vintage. Having been a business major at Georgia Tech, it
would be natural for me to help with estate planning, taxes, and
accounting had I been taken prisoner. The inside out program of public
works and attendant graft, corruption, intimidation and murder was my
way of encouraging scrutiny of similar programs nation-wide. I had been
Postmaster of the Georgia State Senate at 21, so that is why the State
Senate was written instead of the more common oracles, say the Maine
Governor's office or other organs of government and foundations. The
Mozart duet wasn't of my choosing, but it's generally acknowledged as
among the most beautiful pieces of music ever written, so that choice
was a no-brainer. I would have preferred the flute solo from Orpheus,
but that's just me. I purposefully decided against another loathsome
portrayal of racial casts that were very common at that time, so as not
to 'date' the picture and to influence viewers toward tolerance even in
intolerable circumstances. Against opposition, I gave the important Red
character to an African-American actor. (In the short story Red had
been an Irishman.) At the time, that dimmed prospects for box office
success, but given that the flick is now well- received, emulation has
led to further improvement. When we did this one in 1988ish, in
Syracuse, New York, I was attending graduate school of medicine at
SUNY-upstate and working in Max Mozell's lab. At about the same time, I
did dozens of films and won many Oscars for the various ghost writers.
(Gladiator, Good Will Hunting, Cast Away, Mystic River, Eternal
Sunshine of the Spotless Mind, Enemy at the Gates, Green Mile,
Shawshank Redemption, Vanilla Sky, A Beautiful Mind, Forrest Gump, The
Matrix films, The Bourne films, National Treasure films, Pirates of the
Caribbean films, Avatar, Titanic, Lost in Translation, UP, ). The name
of the Mexican town on the seashore was conveyed to me by my old
friend, Frank Arnold, who was Zawataneo (sp?) on vacation while in
medical school. He spelled it for me over the phone while the 'creative
team' and I worked out the flick's details. Since then, the town has
boomed, an unexpected gift to Mexico. I set this one in Maine, to
de-stigmatize inflexible regional prejudices then current. It seems to
have worked. Michael Meyers figured me out, this flick is part of the
series designed to change the world, save the planet, and bring the
human race closer to God Almighty.

I must start by stating that I have watched the movie at least 20
times. This is a masterpiece , work of a genius . And I recommend
everyone to watch this movie at least once in their lifetime .But .. yes there are some buts, when you get over the initial amazement
this movie brings to you you will find out that the plot was not very
solid. There are lots of very big loopholes (potholes ?? ) in the plot.
Like how weird is it that the prisoner is in the same cell for 20 years
.Or, he did not have another cell on his right, or he knew there will
be thunderstorm on the right he decided to flee. I personally felt very
bad after I realized these very very weak links in the movie which
actually weakens the foundation of the whole movie. It's like after
worshiping a person for 20 years of your life you come to know some
thing really bad about him .At one point of time I used to very strongly vote that if any movie
deserve to be the number 1 on IMDb, it's this movie. I am not so
convinced anymore .

15 February 2011
8
This is one of my favorite movies, but it does just go to show the
importance of a great script, good casting and good direction. By that
I mean that, for example, in this movie, the Tim Robbins character
looks like someone who's admirable in every way in the world. But in
real life, I saw Tim Robbins on some TV show where he was interviewed,
and he came across as about as smart as a doorknob. I rate the movie an
8 and rate Tim Robbins a 5. What a jackass. Morgan Freeman is topnotch
as always, and so is James Whitmore. Real professionals. So is Bob
Gunton, the warden. To Tim Robbins credit, this was one of the best
jobs he ever did, and maybe the very best. Also an unusually good job
for Stephen King, who, in this flick, took a break from his usual
moronic horror stories.

******
11 September 2010
10
What would you do if you were convicted of murdering your wife and her
lover, and sentenced to two life-imprisonment terms? Would you just
give up? Would you try to escape? How long would you have to live in
prison before you lose hope? Writer-Director Frank Darabont (The Mist,
The Green Mile) explores these situations, and the themes of integrity,
hope, and freedom.Tim Robbins portrays the character of Andy Dufresne, the man who's
situation was described earlier. Andy claims he didn't commit the
murders, but strong evidence overruled his claims. Did Andy really not
do it? We never really know for sure until later on in the film. When
Andy first arrives at Shawshank prison, he's antisocial, and goes along
with the prison's routine for months. After a few months, however, Andy
starts developing a friendship with Red (Morgan Freeman), a man who can
get practically anything from outside the prison to inside, for a
price. Andy asks him for a rock hammer. The importance of this rock
hammer is evident later on in the film. But Andy's request for this
rock hammer at the beginning of the film allows him to make a new
friend at the prison to keep him company.Andy's time at Shawshank prison causes it to change dramatically.
Within a few years, Andy becomes an important aspect to the prison. His
accounting skills help him receive benefits for himself and his friends
by helping the prison guards with their taxes and other financial
issues. The warden of Shawshank prison also takes interest in Andy, and
soon uses him for a complex money scheme. Andy's role in the prison
allows him to have a library established in the prison, as well as get
beers and other things for his friends. Andy is basically making a new
life for himself in the prison, but he still wants to get out. However,
how many years does it take in the prison for him to give up? How many
years does it take until the prison is your only way of life? This
becomes a problem for many prison inmates, and even to a friend of
Andy's.One of the prisoners, Brookes (James Whitmore) is in this predicament.
Brookes has lived in the prison for so long, for many decades, that
it's all he knows. In the film Brookes gets released out of Shawshank
prison, and is allowed to live a normal life; he has a job and a home.
However, how does one live in a world that has drastically changed over
the past decades? When Brookes was a little boy, cars were rare, but
when he gets released from prison cars were everywhere. It's difficult
to cope with, and Brookes is unable to deal with it. How long until
Andy is the same way?The film portrays two decades of Andy's sentence, with many different
interesting story lines and conflicts mixed in, with many different
characters. 'The Shawshank Redemption' has one important plot involving
Andy's life in the prison and his hopes to escape, along with numerous
side plots involving new inmates and such. The third act of the film is
the quickest, and one of the most interesting parts. It involves a
strong, yet completely unpredictable, resolution to the film. It also
wraps up the lives of the main characters within the film in satisfying
ways.'The Shawshank Redemption' does an excellent job at portraying the
themes of integrity and freedom, and how the prison can sometimes be
some peoples' freedom, with the outside world being feared. Andy's
integrity and hopes to escape from the prison is also a major part of
the film. 'The Shawshank Redemption', adapted from the Stephen King
novel, 'Rita Hayworth and Shawshank Redemption', is a strongly-acted,
well-written, and wonderfully-directed film. It's an amazing and
inspirational piece of work, and probably the most perfect film I've
ever seen. The plot is always at the same constant pace, and is never
slowed down and boring. Every single part of the film is strong,
entertaining, and thoughtful. It truly is a perfect film (this doesn't
necessarily mean it's the the best film ever in the history of cinema).PS: 'The Shawshank Redemption' came out around the same time as
'Forrest Gump' (1994). Both films are amazing and one of the best, but
'Shawshank' was overshadowed by the popularity of 'Gump.' But years
later, 'Shawshank Redemption' was placed even higher than 'Forrest
Gump' on AFI's 100 Years¬Ö 100 Movies list. 'Shawshank' is also
currently the #1 movie of all time on IMDb. Go figure.

******
10 September 2010
10
This movie is a heart felt classic. One of the best of all time. And
thats because it's one of the best story's of all time, combined with a
great plot, great acting, and great script. Quotable, emotional, and
all about redeeming one's life.It contains great tragedy with great camaraderie. The villain, who is
the warden at the Prison, may be one of the most well developed
villains ever. You see his weakness and his strength. You see the same
qualities in yourself in the mistakes you made. And when he collapses
at the end, you hate and pity him at the same time. Andy, the lead
character, is perhaps the greatest heroin. He doesn't possess special
powers to make him great. He possesses the best of human nature. He's
tough, enduring, passionate, smart, and pure of heart.Had to review this movie when I saw the Godfather creeping up on it in
the IMDb top 250. Godfather is not the same caliber. Anyone can
appreciate this movie. There are plenty of people who would feel 'Out
of Touch' with The Godfather, but they arn't reviewing it.

budgeted movie with emphasis on reality.Watching this movie by any

people around.

So as the summary of my post shows, I just registered on IMDb. Never
really cared about writing reviews or rating movies before. But then a
few days ago this movie was on TV. So I watched it, there wasn't
anything with big explosions on any other channel, so I thought why
not. This was before I've even heard of it. Now I know it's #1 on IMDb,
but I didn't have any idea what it was even about when it was on.Anyway, after about 15 minutes I knew there would be something special
about this movie, and boy was I right. I might not be the most
articulate review-writer, as I've seen allot of good reviews on IMDb.

stories, and the depth of it all is just unbelievable. At the end of it
I was just sitting there glaring at the screen, smiling to myself for
witnessing such a masterpiece. So I guess I'll have to settle with
option 1. It's just simply amazing. Watch it. It's not overrated. That
is all.

31 August 2010
10
This movie is THE classic. It is a beautiful, well thought, captivating
drama that really touches you. It is no surprise that's the number 1 by
many reviewers and ultimately #1 in the IMDb Top 250.The plot is rather simple : a man is accused for committing a crime
which he did not take part in. That being said , the movie tells his
life in the prison , thorough the eyes of another character, Red,
portrayed by Morgan Freeman..One can ask how this basic, modest story , can be so astonishing.One of the things that contribute to this magic title , is the rather
humble , very human way that the main character acts . Although
injusticed, he manages to keep his head cool , and makes everything he
can to aid his and their fellas life better , with the help of
elementary things like a cigarette , a beer or even a book.The story is told with a perfect and quiet pace, guided by the words of
Freeman - they transmit a sense of understanding, calming and wisdom
sense that follows through until the very end of the movie.In result, the Shawhank Redemption is the perfect ride - delivers
everything one could want and yet arises meaningfully questions
concerning the purpose and ways of life , that one should not just
ignore.

but what makes him even better is that he has got Morgan Freeman along
side of him as his buddy. Overall, I would recommend this movie to
everyone. It doesn't even matter what kind of movies they like.

everything so completely. Revenge,freedom,happiness,reward for his

cooperates.Well,that's too much for me.The happy ending was nice,but it
was a bit too happy.It really goes straight for that pure part of our
being that would want everything to be spectacular and complete, which
gives us great emotions but ultimately "insults" our common sense.Andy
Dufresne managed to beat the system. It took 18 years but he did it.
Beautiful but I don't buy that. Makes for a great movie but doesn't
leave much room to meditate.However I wouldn't even think of rating
this one less than 9 and really deserves top marks. However,looking

fate of the world, I see no Andy Dufresne's. I see the warden, I see
Red and I see almost all characters but not Andy.He's like Tristan or
Heracles to me,and I don't believe in those hero myths.So,almost
perfect movie,but I'll make and take a point by rating it 9.

22 January 2010
8
I break my reviewing of movies down into five aspects, each worth two
stars, plot, characters, cinematography, soundtrack, and acting. So
here's my broken down review of Shawshank Redemption: Plot: One star.
While the plot flows neatly, is well developed, and doesn't have any
loopholes I noticed, it lacks the originality one would expect from the
top rated movie on IMDb. I have no complaints other than the lack of
providing me with something truly original and complex. It's not a
simple plot, per say, just as it's not an unoriginal plot, but it is by
no means an extremely original or complex plot.Characters: Two stars. No characters went blatantly against psychology,
nor did they ever break their characterization. Characterization was
pretty good and I have no real complaints, all I would have to question
is Andy's character. He was gang raped and got his ass kicked multiple
times and was still this calm, cool, collected guy. I don't see how
that would work out in the real world, so I didn't find that really
believable, but he kept with his characterization and the movie made up
for it with the almost relatable nature of Red's character and how well
the minor characters were developed. That's probably what blew me away
character-wise. No character was exceptionally complex, but all stayed
true to their characterization. However, Andy should have been more
complex than he was, seeing as how he was the main character.Cinematography: Two stars. I have no complaints. Camera angles,
effects, etc. were very good, though there was nothing exceptional
about them that really stood out to me. Though I do realize that it was
pretty well done for a 90's movie. Again, no complaints.Soundtrack: Two stars. Again, very well done, no complaints here. At no
time did it overshadow dialogue, and at no time were there awkward
silences. However, nothing really stood out to me. Not a soundtrack I'd
go on raving to my friends about, but no complaints.Acting: One star. This is obviously unexpected. I mean, Morgan Freeman
and Tim Robbins...I was surprised I didn't find it amazing. But Morgan
Freeman's monologues lacked heart and Tim Robbins' character didn't
give him any room for heart to be placed into it. Again, the best
acting in the movie, in my opinion, would be from the minor characters.
Frank Medrano is worth note, in my opinion, as he was very, very good.
But he didn't remain in the movie long, so him and the other minor
characters didn't make it enough for me to give acting two stars. I'm
sure many people would disagree, though.All in all, I give this movie eight stars and would recommend it to a
friend, but I wouldn't have it rated first on IMDb because, while it
was very good, it didn't strike me as THAT good. There are more
original movies out there that I would recommend before this, though I
do recommend that people watch this movie along with the others.

******
22 January 2010
7
I like this movie all right, I would not rank it on my top movies of
all time and I am also not the type of person to give every movie I see
either a nine or ten or one and two. There are six other numbers in
between and I use them all and I say this one warrants a seven. The
movie about two inmates becoming friends in a corrupt prison has its
charm. It also has its bad points that being the evil prison system
with its mean warden and guards who batter the prisoners. Still, I can
role with that as I can the fact that Tim Robbins is horribly cast in
this film. When he first arrives at Shawshank he does the role
perfectly, however his performance never changes throughout the movie.
He still talks softly, still has the same look, the guy has supposedly
spent some time here so he is going to change even if he does not lose
his hope. There are many positives too though as Morgan Freeman
literally carries the film and I loved the ending escape scenes. I also
like the fact I can just start watching this movie in the middle and
just go on doing something else. Maybe pick it up again later at the
beginning, it is just one of those movies that I can watch it from here
or there and be entertained, but do not necessarily feel I have to
watch it from beginning to end. I know I am now going to be attacked
though as I did not give this movie a nine or ten though. Especially
attacking a movie that so many people think is the greatest thing ever,
however this is just an opinion so just chill. At least I did not like
it and give it a one to lower its score like some people have.

I was feeling a little discouraged the other day so I decided to put
"Old Faithful" in the DVD player. Sure enough, after watching it--for
who knows how many times--I felt inspired again. This movie is the best
movie I've ever seen and maybe the best ever made. It's for anyone who
needs to understand the power of hope--which means it's for everyone
everywhere. I'm so proud it is the top movie on IMDb's Top 250, it sooo
deserves it. I'm so glad it has touched others the way it touched me.
If you haven't seen it--first of all, what planet are you on? lol--but
seriously, go rent it. This is a movie that can change a life. If it
doesn't do something to your insides, you probably don't have a pulse.
I'm so grateful to Stephen King for writing it and to Tim Robbins and
Morgan Freeman and the director and others for making it such a classic
film. THIS is what movie-making was supposed to be.

8 July 2009
7
Very wrong. For so long, I avoided watching this film. I already knew
what it was going to be like: the slightly above average movie with
themes about hope and freedom. An all-out American flick which only a
sentimental American could enjoy, and thus I resented it for holding
the title as the best film ever. When it came to the themes I wasn't
wrong; hope & freedom are the skeleton on which this film is built but
the way it is executed far surpassed any anticipation I could have
mustered, had I actually looked forward to watch it. Morgan Freeman is
sublime as always, Tim Robbins perhaps even better. It slowly develops
and unfolds, which is refreshing compared to all too many fast-cut
films where it seems that the idea is that fast pace equals quality. I
swallowed Shawshank Redemption whole, and even though I do not agree
with its No. 1 ranking, I can now understand. Great movie!

7
Both the story and acting is very good. Though not provoking, the film
doesn't stop when the credits starts rolling. It will make you think.This film slowly takes off and has no really element of suspense. It's
a human story without any fast action. The production contains no
surprises and make the viewer concentrate 100% on the story....but my single issue is how long it takes for the film to get
interesting. For me almost an hour. Maybe this is necessary to build up
the story. A high rated film needs to be great from the start. The
first part is a film true to it's genre and quite predictable.I can's stop thinking that this film's outstanding rating on IMDb, like
some others, maintain their position of obvious reasons. When a film
(or music album)is considered among the best, new reviewers are
affected by this status.

18 March 2009
10
What is the movie about? The movie begins with Andy Dufresne in a Maine
courtroom. He was prosecuted for the murder of his ex-wife and her
boy-friend. He received two life sentences. Being the manager of a bank
he was very shocked at the long sentence. When Andy arrived at Shawshank Prison, life was very difficult. He did
meet one person who became his best friend. Andy was hunted by some gay
prisoners; they beat him up all the time. Red got Andy away from the
gang saving his life. Andy and Red always hung out and took care of
each other after that. Twenty years passed and a new inmate at Shawshank told Andy about a
cell-mate in another prison. This cell-mate was a born killer. He loved
describing his crimes. One of his stories was about two lovers who were
murdered. He continued to say that the woman was the wife of a banker
and he was found guilty and received the same sentence as Andy. Andy
knew that this person he was being told about was himself.During Dufresne‚Äôs time in prison he was the Warden‚Äôs account. Samual
Norton, the Warden, took huge bribes but Andy covered his tracks. When
Andy went to the Warden with evidence that would set him free Norton
had Andy‚Äôs witness murdered. He did not want to be discovered as a
crook.Andy escaped from Shawshank through the sewage pipes with Norton‚Äôs bank
statements and checkbook. Andy Dufresne cashed in the Warden‚Äôs money
and the Norton committed suicide. In the end Red was released from Shawshank and joined Andy in
Zihuatanejo, Mexico.Main Characters:‚Ä¢ Tim Robbins (Andy Dufresne) ‚Äì Andy was a bank manager from a bank in
Bangor, Maine. He spent 20 years in Shawshank being innocent. ‚Ä¢ Morgan
Freeman (Ellis Boyd 'Red' Redding) ‚Äì He was in Shawshank for a murder
he committed when he was a teenager. When Andy arrived at the prison,
Red had already spent 20 years. ‚Ä¢ Bob Gunton (Warden Norton) ‚Äì Seemed
to start off the movie as a tough but fair prison warden. As the movie
went on, he became corrupt. He made prisoners work on roads and farms
but collected money for himself from the State. ‚Ä¢ Clancy Brown (Capitan
Hadley) ‚Äì He was the worst guard at Shawshank. He beat many convicts to
death. He was the Warden‚Äôs ‚Äòpet.‚ÄôMy opinion about this movie: This is one of the best movies I have
seen. The acting was excellent. Even though the movie was set in a
prison, it was a story about real friendship in a difficult setting.

31 July 2008
10
Darabonts film about an innocent banker and his troubles inside a
maximum security prison with a tough warden (Gunton). Andy (robbins)
befriends an inmate whose friendship gives him hope and is the backbone
of the film, Morgan Freeman plays this role superbly in what i think is
the actor's best performance of all time. This is Freeman's film,
though Robbins is great in the lead and Gunton is a hell of an
antagonist. Everything about this film is perfect, so i can completely
see why its the 3rd best film of all time on IMDb. I am a big fan and
have watched it 5 times and wouldn't mind on seeing it again later down
the line. IMDb Rating: 9.2 MY Rating: 10/10

16 June 2008
10
The direction, the acting, the writing, absolutely everything about
this film is masterful.To start off with, the acting is excellent.Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman both give what are arguably the
performances of their career. Robbins acts with subtlety and
understatement, speaking his lines and manipulating his body language
with an effortless grace. Freeman's acting and narration are brilliant,
in particular his monologue near the end.The direction is some of the best, a surprising and resounding foray
into big budget films by Frank Darabont.And of course, the writing is the true shining feature. The creativity
of the story, and the twists that give us the ultimate satisfaction are
rarities among modern American films.This movie, is unquestionably one of the best films of the 1990s, and
perhaps one of the best that has ever been made

22 December 2007
9
Andy Dufresne is a young and successful banker whose life changes
drastically when he is convicted and sentenced to life imprisonment for
the murder of his wife and her lover. Set in the 1940's, the film shows
how Andy, with the help of his friend Red, the prison entrepreneur,
turns out to be a most unconventional prisoner.I've heard much about this movie. I've heard great things about this
movie; wait, scratch that. I've heard brilliant things about this movie
(considering that this is #2 on the top 250 list in IMDb). I didn't
really expect much from this movie because of the long running time and
that this film (I thought) was about redemption. Boy, did it blow me
away!It didn't blow me away as far as people have been blown like a huge
tornado have wrecked the country. It had blown me away like a strong
wind would've knocked me down. It wasn't all that great (like a
masterpiece) but it was an extremely satisfying film.The performances in here were pretty much rock solid as far as playing
two men in jail can go. The score was indeed very pleasing to one's
ears. What else to say? Oh, the story may feel dark but there are some
points where there are some light-heartedness and comedic scenes.This film won me over. It pretty much won everyone over with it's great
story and heart. Overall, as I said, it was extremely satisfying to
watch from beginning to end. It didn't drag a bit even for a two and
almost a half hour film. Watch it and you'll be blown away; but not as
much as many others have been.

******
20 December 2007
10
Perhaps the greatest movie ever made, The Shawshank Redemption tells
the touching and emotive story of the Andy Dufrain. Wrongly convicted
of a dual murder, Dufrain is sent to the to the infamous walls of
Shawshank Prison and the film explores his lifetime of experiences
there.Throughout the film the audience is supplied with a variety of details
and subplots. What is amazing however is the director's ability to
cleverly weave these details into the conclusion and to give each a
remarkable significance.The film features some of the best acting to record and by far the
greatest narrator, Morgan Freeman. The film establishes its themes
perfectly, most notably the paramount bond between the characters
played by Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman.This film will remain a classic for many years to come and the
conclusion will continue to stun and inspire audiences.

years pass by Hollywood will ever be capable of making a film of this
calibre again

31 October 2007
10
I stopped to see Shawshank when I was driving through Cincinnati. The
theater was speckled with moviegoers.. all unaware of what an
incredible cinematic achievement they were about to witness. There
wasn't the slightest sound from the audience....they were mesmerized.
The Jail(was in Mansield,Oh./now torn down), the music, the fantastic
performances from a slew of great actors, Whitmore as Brooks, Robbins
as Andy Dufresne, and Morgan Freeman as Red,..they all did a
spectacular job. This is a film(one of the few)...that will leave it's
audience in tears of happiness. The narration from Freeman is written
with care and this film is crafted and paced with a precision that
Hollywood hasn't seen in a long, long, time. "I hope to see the
Pacific...I hope it is as blue as it is in my dreams". This film
addresses many moral trust issues....from being raped in jail, to
finding a friend amongst criminals, to being unjustly incarcerated and
then shunned when you prove your innocence.."how could you be so
obtuse?".....in the end it is the simplest thing, friendship, that is
synonymous with freedom. This was the last time I was in a theater that
cheered at the credits....and the only time an audience...so small in
numbers...ever did that. One of my top 5 favorite films of all-time.
98/100

27 August 2007
10
There aren't many films that have as much of an emotional pull on you
than the Shawshank Redemption does. Emotions flood through and through
as you watch this movie. One second it's sadness the next it's a
feeling of optimism and hope. A movie which solely takes place in a
prison is one of the most inspiring pieces of art to ever be released.
A film which features a brilliant screenplay by Frank Darabont,
astonishing performances by Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins, an amazing
score by Thomas Newman, delightful cinematography and camera work, and
a film featuring some of the greatest and inspiring themes ever seen in
a film. One of the only films to ever bring me to tears, this beautiful
film will stay with you forever and leave you thinking of life, and the
possibility of wondrous things to come.

******
2 July 2007
10
The film tells the story of Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), an educated
banker sentenced to life for the murder of his wife and her lover. In
prison, Andy inspires his fellow inmates with his courage and humanity
and has a profound effect on Red (Morgan Freeman), an older prisoner,
who has given up hope.Unlike many films of the 90's, "The Shawshank Redemption" has "high
concept" plot premise and is somewhat episodic compared with the tight,
linear narratives of closer structured pictures. This sense of freedom
in the storytelling allows the film to consistently throw up genuine
surprises, as the viewer isn't constantly on guard for clues and plot
points. In hindsight, we tend to forget how successfully director Frank
Darabont leads us to expect a very different resolution."The Shawshank Redemption" does things well that you might not expect.
It has lengthy voice-overs (that actually work well) and it has a sappy
predictable ending, but yet these elements work because they are not
placed in the over-used, meaningless context that movies today place
them in. The voice overs are also consistently used in such a way that
distinct worlds are created. There's a real world inside the prison and
the surreal outside world.These two distinct worlds are created help to place the viewer inside
the halls of the prison, they are no longer watching a movie, but they
are also feeling it.This is a movie that will remain a favorite of the people for many
decades to come. 10/10

assume in some aspect in prison life a lot has changed, but some stay
the same. I'm a sucker for these type of movie that goes through a time
line in peoples lives. I tend to want to know my characters in a movie
then speed through not knowing a small history of the character It is
on my top 20 must see!!!

times and made me love life more than life itself.

10
This is my all-time favorite movie, tied with Good Will Hunting. What a
clear and incredible experience i had trough this!! i'm still
breathless.This incredible film based on a short story by Stephen King (Rita
Hayworth and the Shawshank Redemption) shows the story of Andy Dufresne
(Tim Robbins), an important banker who is convicted to life
imprisonment, accused of the murderer of his wife and her lover;
Dufresne then goes to the Shawshank prison where an incredible story of
hope takes place!, he meets Ellis Boyd Redding, best known as Red
(Morgan Freeman), also a life imprisonment convict who is well
respected in the prison; Dufresne begin to demonstrate that he isn't an
usual convict, gaining admiration and respect off the inmates, and
maintaining the hope in a drab and corrupt prison.It's incredible how the greatness of a human being can promote the most
wonderful feelings in the people, and how a really strong character can
maintain his values, principles and dreams amongst any situation. This
movie touched my soul, gave me a clear and fresh feeling and is a daily
guide to my life! It also demonstrate the importance of the reading,
education and self improvement, challenges, perseverance in reaching
goals, and love of the true meaning of life!.The quality of the film is incredible; the directing of Frank Darabont
is outstanding; Morgan Freeman is absolutely outstanding too!, Tim
Robbins is excellent, their friends roles are touching: Heywood
(William Sandler), Tommy (Gil Bellows) Brooks (James Whitmore); the
prison guards, specially Warden Samuel Norton (Bub Gunton) and Captain
Healey (Clancy Brown) have a good acting also.A movie that is worth to buy and see forever, is the movie that touch
your soul and left a sense of clearness, a movie to teach to your kids
the importance of holding to what you really are, and to always, in any
situation maintain the hope. 10/10 and my all time favorite!!

never fails you down) and acting is superb, in particular Tim Robbins

is the fact that all characters are "one-dimensional stereotype". I
mean that in this movie characters can be extremely positive or
extremely negative, sometimes forgetting that human beings have complex
behavior.

*The Shawshank SPOILERS* In the early '20s, Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), a quiet bank employee,
is arrested, tried and sentenced to life in prison for the murders of
his wife and her lover, murders that he didn't commit.The calm man has to rough up really soon, in order to survive life in
the Shawshank prison, but manages to develop a friendship with a fellow
inmate called Red (Morgan Freeman) and to be employed in the
contability office by the corrupt director of Shawshank, thus helping
his escape plan...When I first watched this movie, a few years ago, I was so in awe that
as soon as I got out of school (where me and my classmates watched it
during a morning without teachers) I went and bought it.It's an instant classic, an inspiring movie, based upon a short story
by Stephen King (!), marvelously written, acted and directed, and fully
deserving of being owned.The Shawshank Redemption: 10/10.

there's red sent to prison at the age of 18 for murder and armed
robbery two polar opposites but in the end they might as well be
family.This is the single most powerful movie ever at the end I was
crying something that has never happened before anyway this is a film
to see before you die words cant honestly explain how great this film
is you have to see it.

1 October 2006
10
I personally think that the way this movie touches me cannot be put
into words. The core of this movie is hope: hope that overcomes every
obstacle placed in your way, the knowing that the wronged people in
life can triumph over evil. This is what Andy Dufresne achieves, and
the tag line of "Fear can hold you prisoner, hope can set you free" is
perfect The underlying theme is friendship, and Andy and Reds
friendship is perfectly portrayed here by Morgan Freeman and Tim
Robbins. They are both fine actors, and I feel here they give career
best performances(although Morgan Freeman is generally good in
everything). Morgan Freeman should of won an Oscar for his subtle
approach to this role - surely his million dollar baby Oscar is a
belated one for this movie too? The directing, the story and everything
combine to make this a special movie - don't worry, the ratings in the
all time list, which always put this movie in the top 5, are not wrong.
This is a movie everyone must see!!!

reason the Shawshank Redemption is looked down upon is because it is
flawless.And even if that isn't true, that is how I feel about it.10/10.

22 September 2006
9
I do think some films get better the more you view them. "Shawshank" is
such a film. Whever I stumble across it on a cable channel, I am simply
unable to break away from it, even though I've seen it a dozen times.
The best films are "simple stories, well told." From the script, to the
acting, to the direction, to the sets, and - most importantly - in its
message, "The Shawshank Redemption" is absolutely first-rate. It's
always fun to see a wronged man win in the end, but in this story it is
the manner in which Andy prevails that is so gripping. The scene in
which Tim Robbins as Andy ponders if he is in some way responsible for
his fate because of his thoughts is amazing. And Morgan Freeman's
greatest film moment comes when he faces the parole board one more
time. Most movies blow from your mind minutes after the final credits,
this one stays with you forever. I'm ready to see it again.

10
i've seen the top 50 films in the IMDb top 250 category and a number of
times I've felt that a movie wasn't worth its ranking. the shawshank
redemption fits this bill in not being placed number one. and this
coming from a die-hard god father fan must surely mean something. the
storyline, the cinematography and the acting are all masterpieces in
their own right. the story of a wronged person accepting his fate and
then changing it is remarkable, for everyone relates to it, though
maybe not to the extent portrayed here. kudos to stephen king and frank
darabont and the actors for a great movie. its a real pity that it won
no Oscars. this is one movie i would have hated to miss. truly
exceptional.

4 September 2006
10
*spoilers*The first time I saw "The Shawshank Redemption",I was simply blown away
by how powerful this movie is. There are no action sequences or
romances, but the subtle drama of a man who is wrongly accused is
easily identifiable, possibly because we realize that it could happen
to anyone. What makes the main character (Andy Dufrene) find the strength to
survive his term of life in prison is his knowledge of his innocence,
and his friendship with Red, a convicted murderer, who is slowly
reforming throughout the movie. The end of the movie is perhaps one of
the most uplifting scenes I have ever watched, as justice finally
prevails, due to Andy's determination and careful planning.I never get tired of this movie. From the beginning of the movie where
Andy considers murder, to his incarceration for that same
murder(ironically committed by someone else), and his long stay in
prison under a cruel warden, and finally the best-ever use of a Raquel
Welch art poster. Ever.I highly encourage this movie to anyone who hasn't seen it. It is a
classic, and the acting is superb. Even smallest roles are memorable.

10
This is one of the best stories of freedom in the world. It shows how
the human heart can work to get you out of the worst situations. Sure i
never cried during watching it but it made me feel good.This movie tells a tale back in 1949, a man is convicted of the murder
of his wife and her lover(sound familiar 'Green Mile'/Stephen King
fans?). Of course with all Stephen King's twisted books/movies... he
didn't do it but he is sent to prison anyway. Since prisoners were
thought of lesser human in the 40's-70's if you were caught doing
something you weren't suppose to(or if yo u just annoy the guards) you
are beaten badly. Luckily Andy Dufrense makes acquaintances with the
warden and guards. He makes friends with 'Red' Redding(Nicely done by Morgan Freeman), a
man who can get you anything from the outside. They bond together with
other inmates and conquer over the warden. BUT one day a new inmate
comes in and tells the story of how he knows Andy is instant.The rest people can figure out for their own but they have to be
careful... though this is one of Stephen King's rare dramas, it will
have the evilness and twists that we all love him for. Plus look for
the most feel good ending in the world. I'm honest this ending will
shock you so much and make you want to know more of what happened.

20 August 2006
10
If you have never seen this film do your self a favour, go rent the DVD
now and prepare to have yourselves one of the best evenings
entertainment you are ever likely to have in front of a TV set. Right
from the opening scenes when you see the dramatic sweeping aerial shots
of the prison you know that you are in for something special. When I
first read the synopsis for this film, and saw it described as a brutal
prison drama I thought it wasn't the kind of film I would enjoy. Boy
was I wrong I think that Shawshank is the best film I have ever seen.
Its much more than a brutal prison drama it's a film of friendship,
injustice, resolve and most of all hope. The film tells the story of
Andy wrongly convicted and imprisoned for the murder of his wife and
her lover and the friendship he forms with Red a long serving inmate.
Andy isn't like most of the other prisoners he's quiet, educated, plays
chess and has a middle class background. Red is from the streets a
seasoned prisoner who serves his time with weary resignation. Their
unlikely friendship blossoms and grows in to love, of the non-sexual
type, and it's this bond this friendship that is the centre of the
film. The performances given by Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins are
astounding, sorry Tom Hanks but I think Morgan/Tim were robbed of the
Oscar that year. I love the tag line from the film "Fear can hold you
prisoner but hope can set you free" WOW an amazing, moving triumph of a
film, if you haven't seen it yet what are you waiting for! Watching The
Shawshank Redemption is one of those things you have to do before you
die.

31 July 2006
10
A heartbreaking story fraught with Passion, Loss, A Dream, and
Friendship. There's only so much i can say about a film that is loved
by millions and yet misunderstood by more. It's the visual version of a
musical ballad. A soft and thoughtful piece and yet created by a hard
centre and churned by the brilliant hands of Frank Darabont and the
great acting of both Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman. A True Classic."Andy Dufresne, is sent to Shawshank Prison for the murder of his wife
and secret lover. He is very isolated and lonely at first, but realises
there is something deep inside your body, that people can't touch and
get to....'HOPE'. Andy becomes friends with prison 'fixer' Red (Morgan
Freeman), and Andy epitomises why it is crucial to have dreams. His
spirit and determination, leads us into a world full of imagination,
filled with courage and desire. Will Andy ever realise his dreams...?"

13 May 2006
10
This is possibly the best film ever made. Everything from the script
and acting to the camera work and set are remarkable. Based on a
Stephen King novella, it is easily the best adaption from a written
story ever put to film. Tim Robbin's certainly deserved an Oscar for
this film, his performance was moving yet not overpowering. Even though
the audience is left out of the story in certain parts, we still feel
strongly for his character Andy Dufresne. Morgan Freeman is perfect,
even though he's not the Irishman that was intended for the role. He
narrates the film with ease and we connect to his character as if we
were a part of the movie. Frank Darabont, director of the film, allowed
us to feel what Andy was feeling through the use of small stories and
camera shots. The immensity of the prison can be felt instantly from
our first viewing. The connection the audience makes to the film as a
whole makes The Shawshank Redemption what it is: one of the best films
ever made.

10
After watching useless film after useless film, I always come back to
this. It acts as a benchmark and I must remind myself to watch it more
as I find myself become more accommodating to the rubbish which is
being released these days. How many films do you find yourself counting
the minutes till the end or where the media has created a publicity
storm to cloak the fact their film isn't worth the huge budget they
spent on it? After watching King Kong at Christmas I felt depressed, as
here was a truly bloated, poorly acted, lazily directed, piece of film
which was getting rave reviews from the critics and public alike.
Please feel free to argue against me, but the fact that so few are
willing to state the obvious, that the film wasn't great, just alright
at best, highlights a continuing trend in todays society, that of
applauding mediocrity.

******
7 January 2006
9
This film, a modern fable, is an amazing success story - not in
monetary terms, but in terms of reputation. It began as just another of
many dramas, in this case based on a Stephen King story, and has
emerged as possibly the best film of the decade, the '90s (#2 of the
IMDb top 250 as of this writing, right up there with The Godfather!).
The story begins as another prison drama but gradually metamorphoses
into a poetic commentary on friendship and the scope of life. The main
character (Robbins) is sent to prison in the late forties for
supposedly murdering his wife. It really is a men's picture; there are
literally no female characters (the wife appears for a few seconds
early on in flashback and that's about it, besides a complaining
shopper later; oh, and, of course, Rita Hayworth pops in as herself).
The film holds many surprises in store for the viewer as the story
progresses, not the least of which is the subtle revelation, towards
the end, that the main character may just be Freeman's (how appropriate
is that name!). If one had to pick one reason for this film's success
(and there are probably several), it's that it's probably the best
depiction of friendship between men on celluloid - no cutesy
buddy-buddy stuff, no homo-erotic connotations - just a solid, adult
basis for two men to bond over and remain friends.But there are many other, I dare say, cool aspects to the film. Most
everyone who has seen this has at least two or three favorite scenes
which they remember forever and which they watch over and over. My
personal favorite is the one on the roof, where Andy (Robbins) makes
his bid for a slightly better existence, taking a big risk with the
captain of the guards (Clancy Brown, always intimidating). It's a
turning point in the picture and shows two important matters recurring
through it: taking a risk and using your intelligence. Andy turns out
to be very smart; he's always using his head. And the ultimate
switchback of the picture, the comeuppance of the evil warden (Bob
Gunton, excellent as scum dressed in pricey suits), shows you that a
film doesn't need a standard shootout to depict the ultimate justice or
retribution. No, if you use your brains, you can really get back at
those oppressive forces seeking to dehumanize you, abuse you, and lord
over you. Boy, can you get them back. I mean really - has there ever
been a bigger turnaround in the history of cinema? OK, maybe this is
why this film is rated so high - you just can't get a better release
from frustration than this, not on film. Here, payback isn't just a
bitch - she's the daughter of Satan sent to take you to hell.Another thing to mention is that this film covers about 20 years of
time. That's a long stretch. The film itself is over 2 hours running
time. Most films, even the best ones, with so much to cover, can't help
but sag in places, especially historical pieces. But that's not the
case here. Writer-director Darabont, who also worked on the even longer
"The Green Mile" later, shows us how to create films which are always
interesting to watch, whether at the one hour or 2-hour mark. Or am I
being obtuse?

******

Every time I watch this movie Its like watching it for the first time.
Everything about it works the characters the story and the direction.
This movie should be number 1 on IMDb.com. Tim Robbins gives an

killing his wife a man she was having an affair with. Robbins provides
a subtle quality to his character which has a lot of depth though not
entirely apparent on the surface you can tell it is there. Morgan
Freeman Plays the character red as well as narration for the story. His
voice provides a very powerful way of pushing the story forward which
combined with an excellent score finishes off the movie and makes it a
must see for anyone.

Shawshank IS a very good film but it has too many clich√© characters and
situations AND script holes that one can drive a truck through. Gee,
this must be from a Stephen King story. Actually, it's from two of his
short stories. With King its often quantity and not quality. Despite
that, The Shawshank Redemption is worthwhile.What this film does have is terrific performances from the entire cast
and a sense that an honest man can remain honest, despite the worst of
circumstances. The scenes with the great character actor James
Whitmore, especially those of his trying to cope after his release, are
very well done.The last ten minutes is splendid and almost redeems the rest of the
picture. It gives this film an 8 instead of a 6 in my scale.

******
12 October 2005
10
The Shawkshank Redemption's - Review Get busy living get busy dying! Is
merely one of the many great messages this 1994 masterpiece has to
offer. Originally written as a short story by Stephen King 'The
Shawkshank Redemption' has come to be one of the greatest movies of all
time being nominated for 7 Oscars, and winning 11 various other awards.
Directed by Frank Darabont it stars Tim Robbins as 'Andy Dufresne' and
Morgan Freeman as 'Red'. This earlier 19th century film is delivered to
its audience directly through the eyes of 'Red' giving us a strong one
mined impersonation of the prison and the people who make up its walls.The life that Andy once had drastically changed when he is charged
guilty for the murder of his wife and her lover. Made to serve 2 life
sentences Andy soon got to grips with his new surroundings. But one day
he pushes aside all moral judgement on one decision that almost as him
killed but his heroism and sheer courage gains him respect from other
inmates at which point he slowly becomes good friends with 'Red' the
man who can get you things. With 'Hope' on his side Andy goes on to do
great things! The movie rests deeply on the persona built up around
Andy. To some respect the filmmakers regarded him as a religious symbol
and used brief yet powerful references to reflect on this. He would
take up massive challenges helping out the majority all so that I could
simply create a sense of freedom or retained hope in his life. He
conveys a particular demeanour that people tend to associate with
'Christ' and as 'red' quite rightly says, "He strolled. Like a man in a
park without a care or worry".'Character Development' is a complete different term altogether in this
movie, taking us as far into the unknown. Darabont encouraged something
different, with twists and turns in the story we are continually struck
with new surprises. By pushing boundaries of modern day cinema,
Darabont exercised in presenting us with new, interesting but most
importantly feel-good and exiting Characters. This would have never
been possible without the powerful and striking performances from both
'Tim Robbins' and 'Morgan Freeman', as individuals they play there
separate roles with a convincing harmony. But as a pair they pitch
together as if you were husband and wife, the acting is flawless there
chemistry works in perfect balance and there absolute ability to grasp
the audience in continuous narrative is something that is rarely
witnessed in a movie.While the characters are unbelievably amazing and the script is
excellent, it's the extraordinary way this movie uses cinematography to
give us a hardened view into the reality of this film. Thick walls,
large inescapable fences, and confined spaces all remind us of this
place we have been brought to. This is spanned onwards with the common
use of relentless Guards marching and the heavy cell bars slamming open
and shut. In a way reinforcing the dull existence these men have to
live with. This is all backed by outstanding crane and helicopter shots
from the Coen Brother arguably some of the best camera work to date,
the lighting brought not only outstanding quality from the work but it
helped to create meaning and build layers deep into the story. Finally
the editing was set at a perfect pace and even with regular leaps into
future the team manages to maintain a high standard from beginning to
end.It is considered as a feel-good classic. But in hindsight thoughts four
walls hold a more grime, corrupt and depressing existences. But it is
the exultance of Writer/Director Frank Darabont who unlike most
directors forces on the real human issues head on, dealing the problems
of male rape, assault, murder, and abuse in a very effective way. But
by encouraging more enthuses on the strong emotional relationships
created between you and the characters Darabont was able to stray
audiences away from this harsh reality into uplifting portrayals of
Andy and his great achievements.Its quite amazing to think how such a great movie would fail to make an
impact on the big screen and would only pick up fame after it was
realised to video in 1995. But its success was well received and people
soon began to understand what they had been missing. But its only now
10 years on that we begin to see how its success continues to be
harvested and filtered through into many modern day movies.My Personal Rating for this Movie 9/10

******

and there were some good moments but overall it was a bit too clich√©d.

string-led score from James Horner or Hans Zimmer.

7 October 2005
10
This could be the greatest movie ever. It's hard to believe anyone can
watch it and not be touched by it in some way. Who can't identify with
the conception of hope, truly the foundation of this picture. There is
so much raw emotion, and the movie bears upon many. With such brilliant
performances by the cast, and the amazing job done by Frank Darabont
and co., the viewer becomes immersed in the film, and feels each of
those emotions. It becomes a very personal experience that way. I've not discussed this movie with anyone, at any length, that didn't
love it. It is worthy of every bit of acclaim it continues to receive.
I can't say that The Shawshank Redemption has changed my life as it has
for some, but every time I watch it I'm drawn in again. And every time
I run the emotional gamut it takes us through. It is the one film of
which I will never tire. -Jason Stanley

2 October 2005
10
This movie is the greatest prison movie I have ever seen. The storyline
is original and the performance of Tim Robbins is superb. The movie is
about Andy Dufresne is convicted of the double murder of his wife and
her lover and tells the story of his double life sentence behind bars
at Shawshank prison which uses religion as a form of rehabilitation.
During his sentence he is bashed constantly for three years until he
meets a fellow inmate Ellis "Red" Redding who is asked by Dufresne to
help him escape. With his escape comes the signature scene as Andy
escapes through the sewers to freedom. The end of the film highlights
the ability of two friends to overcome adversity to achieve a central
goal. The screenplay is superb as this is based on the novel by one of
the best or the best horror of all time, Stephen King. The movie is a
movie that explores the REAL story behind bars and the ability of
people to escape mentally and spiritually with rehabilitation

30 September 2005
10
I wholeheartedly agree with reismark's review of the film. It is
excellent. I want to note, however, as the treasurer of a library
system, that people should remember that rental and purchasing are not
the only options. If you learn about your local libraries, you'll find
that many of them, perhaps most of them, have collections of video on
VHS and DVD which rival rental stores. In most instances, these
materials circulate without charge, although some libraries charge a
nominal fee to rent very recent titles. In the library system to which
I belong, even rental titles are potentially available free, since we
insist that there must be at least ONE copy in the system which
circulates without a fee.

27 September 2005
9
I saw this movie at the end of a particularly bad and miserable day in
my life and it is safe to say that I was not particularly looking
forward to this one.Two and a half hours later I was on my feet again and was once more
prepared to look the world in the eyes. Such is the power of this
movie.Tim Robbins plays a sincere man who is sent to to jail for a crime he
did not commit. Inside, he meets extraordinary human beings, all of who
you will fall in love with within minutes of meeting them. Chief among
these is the character of Red, played by none other than the legendary
Morgan Freeman.Together with Andy and Red you learn about life and friendship and the
evils inherent in human nature. You laugh with them, are sad with them
and feel their pain, and in the end, when the two friends meet again on
a remote beach years later, you finally break down and cry with them.This movie is emotionally powerful and reminds us once again what the
movies should be.It is not sentimental in any way, and that is a rarity these days. And
if you do not feel sad, and your heart does not beat faster with Morgan
Freeman's soliloquoy at the end, you cannot call yourself human. For,
then, you have missed one of the greatests gifts one can receive: a
passion for life.

22 September 2005
9
I have seen this movie twice and I enjoyed it as much the second time
as I did the first time. Of course the surprise-effect is gone the
second time because you know how the story goes, but that isn't a
problem. The story is brilliant: it's amazing how clever Andy is! The
acting is outstanding. Morgan Freeman proves again he is a top-talent
and also Tim Robbins is wonderful.The story has everything: it's very sensitive and it shows some aspects
of prison that aren't shown in other prison movies. It think (but I'm
not sure because I have never been in prison) it gives a unique, but
realistic view on the prison life and the many feelings prisoners are
confronted with doing their time. The example of very tragic but so
true I think. The guy has been his whole life in prison, that's the
only life he knows and when he is released, he doesn't know how to
built up a life in the real world because the world he know before
prison doesn't exist anymore.Frank Darabont proves he is a remarkable director and that he is made
for directing prison-movies. "The Green Mile" is also an excellent and
touching prison drama. It almost unbelievable that "The Shawshank
Redemption" didn't won any Academy Award. But of course you can't deny
that fact that the competition was fierce that year with also "Forrest
Gump" in the running.Highly recommendable prison-drama with great acting performances by
Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins.9/10

10
I hope you watch this film, and you are found better for it. This movie is all about acting in the best interest of yourself and
others, and the evil that checks our good motive. Morgan Freeman plays
the role of a lifetime, and that's saying a lot because Morgan has had
quite a few outstanding performances. I do think this was his best. The
reason I think that are the extremes that Freeman's character goes
through from utter despair ("somestimes all I can think about is ...")
to highest hope.The movie does so many things well, but the two most important for me
were Freeman's Narration as a whole ("tall drink of water") and the use
of the letter device through narration. Freeman narrating the letter
which read,"I hope this letter finds you well," is one of the most
pleasant lines I think I have even heard in any movie. It had to make
Freeman's character feel better about "his friend" (though he may not
have needed that), but it is as if Andy Dufresne knew that Red would be
struggling, and he needed the feeling of calmness to get him through
this period. The treasure hunt device and the physical scene of that
device is movie making at it's finest. The shot up the hill to the tree
(great focal point), the stone wall, it was all perfect.I would that we all would find our friend on the beach of self content
for fond embrace.

15 September 2005
10
This movie is perfect in construction, with just the right amount of
feel-goodiness added but not so much as to make one wretch. A portrait
of the strength of the human spirit, and the awesome power of hope. I
love the feeling of hope that this movie inspires in the viewer. I
haven't met anyone who doesn't love it (still awaiting the DVD's return
as I lent it to a friend about 4 months ago!) The only negative comment
I've ever heard about it is the ending. Some die-hards think the movie
should end with Red in the coach on his way to find Andy, but not show
their meeting on the beach as its too corny. I disagree. I think that
after the whole battle to escape, and wondering if they will etc,
people needed the closure that seeing them meet offered. If they'd
hugged and cried that would have been too much for me, but it was done
perfectly. With Red, casually strolling down the beach towards Andy and
starting to laugh. I'm getting goose-bumps just thinking about it now.My favourite movie.
