14 September 2005
10
Outstanding. Never has a film gripped so powerfully before. Some films
are great and hold you well enough, but this absolute powerhouse of a
film keeps me glued, and is a great tribute to Hollywood, the great
Stephen King short story, and of course a great tribute to all the
things that make hope and freedom so wonderful. Tim Robbins gives the
performance of his life, as Andy Dufresne. A strong-headed man who is
sent to Shawshank prison, wrongfully accused of "murdering his wife,
and the fellow she was banging." With that in mind, it is
excruciatingly tense and powerful, as we watch Andy adapt to prison
life, form a beautiful friendship with 'Red' the convict who knows how
to get things, (played brilliantly by Morgan Freeman, who in my opinion
deserved to win the Best Actor Oscar) and of course see him handle
himself around those out to get him, which spans from other prisoners
to the warden, who he helps turn the prison into a business, due to his
good experience as a banker, the occupation which he held before being
convicted. But as the picture goes on, you can see the yearning to get
out. He is a bird that has been caged wrongfully, and when you see how
long he has been locked away for, even though he didn't do it it really
makes for stunning and compelling viewing. The ending is beautifully
scripted, and the mood is outstanding. Frank Darabont has created an
exceptional film, with realistic talents and people we can care for.
The stereotype of the prisoner is made into something better, and the
overall experience of this film is magnificent, with fantastic
memorable quotes, and an exchange of good to bad atmosphere, which at
one point makes you feel good watching it, but then shows the awful
atrocities and seriousness of the situation. This complex style of
direction and storytelling is amazing, and the ending is top notch, I
won't spoil this bit though. You wanna know how good it is? Then watch
it and be dazzled by this truly remarkable film. 10/10

******
12 September 2005
10
A Prison Movie. An all-male cast (except for Rita Hayworth). Violence.
A title guaranteed to sprain your jaw. When Shawshank hit theatres in
1994, odds were decidedly against it becoming a huge success. It would
be nice to think that an ultimately upbeat, earnest, modernist take on
the films of Frank Capra would immediately find a sympathetic and
appreciative audience. But that would be a fairy tale, and life, like
prison, is no fairy tale.The film has the cheek to ask Which is worse, being a murderer, or
being a lousy husband? Certainly the audience must ask itself this of
the main character, Andy, played by Tim Robbins, who is sent to
Shawshank Prison in 1947 for the murder of his wife and her lover.
Introverted, bookish, proud, his fate is uncertain until he attracts
the attention of the prison "finder" Red, played by Morgan Freeman.
Together the two men must find emotional healing, spiritual redemption,
and hope, if they are to survive.Adroit and expertly manipulative, the film's pace is dictated by the
deathless narration of Freeman, who could hold an audience spellbound
while reciting phone book listings; or, suspend utter disbelief at a
patently preposterous storyline. Nor are characterizations any less
preposterous, from the sociopathic Warden, to the sadistic Head Guard,
to the grandfatherly Librarian, to the manic-youthful Young Punk. But
if the characters seem too archetypal to be true, it is a necessary,
and tolerable evil in this fairy-tale set in a prison.As I said, life is no fairy-tale, and prison movies rarely get to
top-ten status. But sometimes some good does prevail, and redemption
often stands in wait for those who dare reach out to it. As a first-run
cinematic release Shawshank was not a great success. But as a
commercial video, the film has achieved high status, and is voted year
after year as a top consumer favorite. Cinematically near-perfect,
visually breathtaking, Shawshank is a state-of-the-art example of the
power of film to tell stories, and is rightly considered a must-see by
most film reviewers.

******
11 September 2005
10
One night when i was browsing through the channels and my dad was doing
laundry. The Shawshank Redemption came up and he said it was one of his
favorite films. I had no idea why until i watched it. The movies
performances, specifically Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman, are both
incredibly complex and are both Oscar quality. The set of the prison
and supporting cast and extras are all masterfully organized. The story
is crisp and original, and has deep emotion to it. This movie received
7 Oscar nominations and won none, i believe because Forrest Gump stole
all the thunder. But if it were my choice, The Shawshank Redemption
would have won Best Picture and is in my mind the best film i have ever
seen.

******
10 September 2005
10
Awe-inspiring...an amazing emotional journey and a great philosophical
piece. A true work of art. But where do I start? The casting is
excellent, the characters all mesh seamlessly and effortlessly into the
storyline and the interactions seem real and believable throughout. The
philosophical connotations that the movie brings with it are thought
provoking; showing the shades of society, not as blacks and whites (as
in good and bad, not as race) but as shades of grey. The reversal of
expected integrity of character comparing the guards and the inmates is
excellent and adds depth to the story and something to think about. It
shows the good and evil that exist on 'both sides of the fence' so to
speak. The imagery and visual artistry throughout the entire film is
done flawlessly. The drab neutral colours (yes colours... I'm Canadian)
of the prison itself and the clothing of both the guards and the
inmates set the stage for the dreary and sometimes dark undertones for
the story quite well. I am not old enough to know whether the type of
weapons, outfits, vehicles etc. used as props in the movie are accurate
but they seemed to be in my eyes and fit the time period. I could go on
but words alone do not do the movie justice, you have to go see it.

perfect it's hard to put it into words, every little detail is
stunning. Maybe my opinion is not the most objective because this has

the first time I saw it. I could't get it of my mind for a couple of
days. And still, after seeing it over 20 times, I often think about it
and smile. The part when Andy escapes and the next 30 minutes after
that you can't stop smiling, it's so perfect. The biggest star must go
to Morgan Freeman who gives this movie even more deep and feeling. To
everyone who haven't seen it yet, do it, you will not regret it.

Like many people I didn't bother seeing this movie when it was in
theaters, and then I forgot about it, it wasn't till many years later
that I decided to give this movie a chance.After reading all the praises for this movie I decided to rent it. The
first time I watched it I fell asleep, I was bored out of my mind. A
couple of months past I decided to give it a second chance and watched
it all the way through and thought, what was so great about that movie,
nothing special. Another couple of months pass and I spot the 10th
anniversary ed. for sale, so I bought it because I liked the artwork on
the cover. I saw it for the third time and I fell in love with it. It's
definitely one of my favorite movies of all time.Why the academy didn't award this masterpiece an award is beyond me.
The directing is perfect, it's perfectly casted and acted, every actor
is believable in their roles, the story, adapted from a short story by
Steven king is what stands out. This is the ultimate movie about hope;
never give up hope no matter what.I've noticed many people bashing this movie, I say just give it a
chance, I thought it was crap on my first viewing; it wasn't until my
third viewing that I realized how incredible this movie was.This movie changed my life. Whenever I'm going through a hard time in
my life, I pop in this movie and realize that no matter what you're
going through, you can come out clean on the other side.

******
31 August 2005
10
When Andy Dufresne, a young and successful banker, discovers his wife
in bed with another man his life takes a dramatic turn for the worse.
When the lovers' bodies are discovered, shot repeatedly with bullets
from a gun linked to Andy, he becomes wrongly imprisoned. Sent to a
maximum security prison run by a corrupt and over-zealous religious
warden he struggles to hang on to hope of returning to the outside
world and reclaiming a sense of normality. After a period of isolation
he finally approaches one of the other inmates, a convict called Red
who is the only person in Shawshank Prison guilty of their crime. What
begins as a business partnership between two characters, who would be
unlikely to cross paths in the real world, quickly turns into a
lifelong friendship. Together they manage to fight impossible odds to
survive and prove that both hope and the possibility for redemption
never die.I have heard many people rave about 'The Shawshank Redemption' over the
years but have only just gotten around to watching it myself, and the
praise heaped upon this film scarcely do it justice. This is not just
the story of a man wrongly imprisoned, or the astonishing reality of
life behind bars, but an emotional drama which reels you in from the
onset. The movie is quite lengthy however I found myself unable to
press the stop button as the level of interest was maintained steadily
throughout, and I kept wanting to "watch a bit more". It has been a
long time since I have actually cried while watching a film or sat on
the edge of my seat literally in suspense, but 'The Shawshank
Redemption' managed to make me do both.The characters are what make this movie brilliant and the casting of
Morgan Freeman as Red and Tim Robbins as Andy was spot on. They managed
to convince me that I was watching real life and actual circumstances
rather than just a realistic portrayal of the prison world. Their
reactions and behaviour were original but suited the film, and really
highlighted how easy it can be to become a victim but that you do not
have to accept that role forever.I felt inspired by the ideas raised and loved how my mind was
encouraged to consider certain beliefs and rules in society. This movie
challenges some of the toughest issues facing us in the modern age,
even though the film was set over a period from the 1940's ¬ñ 1980's.
Frank Darabont has produced an excellent movie which does not
disappoint in any way. I would recommend 'The Shawshank Redemption' to
anyone over the age of about 15 as a brilliant and enlightening drama.

action, horror and FX movies. Hats off to the actors, the script writer

meaningless lines. I've used IMDb since it was born, and this is the
first time I've actually felt like telling the world a movie is worth
watching. It's probably also the last time, so just ban me from
commenting further.

1 August 2005
9
Rarely has a director connected so well to the spirit of a story, and
with the impeccable work of Morgan Freeman, whose narration is nothing
short of perfect, and Tim Robbins' everyman, "Shawshank" delivers an
almost perfect film. Frank Darabont has opened up the short story and
created a work that explores what lurks in the souls of people. He has
added details that allow us to understand how the human spirit manages
to survive in the worst of conditions. He also shows us that beauty
lies in just about any place in this world.The film moves very well, taking us for a long and rewarding ride.
Characters age and evolve, discovering how their relationships with
others always have consequences. Tim Robbins remains at the center, and
he becomes, for most of the film, an observer, our representative in a
world that could destroy you if you let it.We relate to the men of "Shawshank" because they are our
representatives in a microcosm of society. We observe as we participate
and see our reflections in a mini study of emotions and mind games.

29 July 2005
10
The Shawshank Redemption is without a doubt my favourite film of all
time. Ranked 2 in the top 250 films it is clear others agree with me.
And when you watch this you will too. The plot may sound familiar (guy
goes to jail, guy escapes jail) but this is nothing like i have seen
before. It's about Andy Dufresnes (Tim Robbins) determination and
persistence which keeps him going through his 19 years. But the film is
also about Ellis Boyd Redding (Morgan Freeman) commonly known as "Red".
He does not claim innocence and is the only guilty man in Shawkshank.
When Dufresne arrives Red makes a bet he'd be first to crack. But Andy
stays strong which surprises Red. He uses this strength to keep going
day after day and he passes this feeling onto Red when he tells him of
a box planted under the tree. This gives Red some hope, It gives him
something to look forward to and that will keep him going day by day.
Without Andy Red would have nothing in life. And when you have nothing
in life like Brooks did... There is nothing to keep you going onto the
next day. This film is brilliantly scripted. The acting is top class
and you get the feel of the innocent man amongst the guilty. The
corrupt guards and wardens add to Andys story of wrong convictions and
unfairly treated. He just happens to be the only innocent man in
Shawshank.

18 July 2005
10
Brilliance. Total Brilliance. From the perfectly casted roles, to the haunting music; the
all-encompassing narrative provided by Morgan Freeman, to the
magnificent storyline and plot, this movie blends all these elements of
good film-making. So much so, that even something as commonly
overlooked as having just enough comedy to provide relief from total
somberness, but not enough to distract from the misery of prison life
brought by the equally criminal actions of those in authority at the
prison; this, too, was executed with perfection. This movie is the blueprint for what I would consider to be the perfect
movie. I challenge anyone to come up with something they would "do
better" than what those who made this movie did.

******
6 July 2005
10
Honestly, whenever you think of a good movie, what's the first thing
that comes to mind when you think about it? Is it the story? The
characters? The setting? How about the acting? The writing? Or, most
importantly in some cases, the directing? Did the movie go in the
direction that it needed to go?Some, if not all people think of at least one of these things. Some
think about it all, and judge the movie by how well it held up under
all of these matters it had to worry about.I'm one of the latter. And I think that not only is "The Shawshank
Redemption" the greatest adaptation of a story ever, it quite possibly
might be the greatest film, ever. And if it isn't, it's damn close.Seriously, seeing that "Shawshank" is at #2 on the all time 250 is, at
least to me, a testament to how under-rated and under-appreciated it
really is. Now, don't get me wrong... being the second greatest film
ever is quite an honor, and any film lucky enough to receive it must be
pretty damn good anyway. But seeing it in second place just reminds me
of the 1995 Academy awards. This movie was nominated for 7 awards, and
do you know how many it went home with? 0. In a just world, it would
have swept.But I'm being a little too bias, so let's just get on with the movie,
eh?Anyways, the movie takes place in the late 1940's and is about a man
named Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins, in the absolute finest performance of
his entire career) who, in the very beginning of the film, is convicted
of murdering his wife and her lover. Of course, we know he isn't
guilty, but either way, he's sent to live out two life sentences at
Shawshank, one of the toughest prisons in the world. Meanwhile, Red
(Morgan Freeman, also in his finest performance) is denied parole
again, after serving 20 years of a life sentence.It should be known to most of you that this movie is entirely based off
of a 90 page short story by Stephen King called "Rita Hayworth and
Shawshank Redemption", which was featured in one of his collections.
The book is entirely made up of Red's passages, which means that in the
movie he's going to become the narrator. Normally, this would become
intrusive, but here, it shines. It's also important to point out that
there is an entire scene in the movie that was never in the book, where
Andy rebels and plays music over the intercom for the entire prison to
hear. This not only shows a powerful thing called "hope", it shows just
how talented Frank Darabont really is. After all, he's responsible for
another underrated gem "The Green Mile".But back to the story. Andy arrives at the prison, and after a very
crappy first night in which he didn't make a sound, he finally meets
Red, and they become very good friends while he's there for 20 years.
We see him struggle, get abused by the "sisters", build a library, do
accounting because his life on the outside was that of an accountant
and many other things. One of the most powerful scenes of the film is
when he is put in the hole for 2 months because he snooped around too
much with the warden (Bob Gunton, in his usual asshole role) about the
person who really killed his wife.Top that off with amazingly good co-star performances by William
Atherton and Clancy Brown, and it can't be beat.Anyways, yeah, I'm not saying anything else except that this is truly
deserving of the best film honors here, and I'd like to see it.An honest to god amazing film.

(andy and red). It's true to life with the little details of when it

under his wing and tells him moral after moral. Great movie, i can watch it over and over again, which, normally i cant

little extra special. Watch it!!!!

10
This is simply a film that you would struggle to find a flaw with. The
performances are wonderful, the story is involving and deep, the
characters are likable and understandable, and the whole climax to the
story is satisfying and rewards you for having stayed the course. It's
funny, it's moving, and it presents an incredible perception on the

round - believe me, they'll thank you for it. This is one film that
really is a must-see.

******
16 May 2005
10
In the 11 years since the release and realization of the brilliance of
this film, I'm sure many, many legions of people have written reviews
that summarily praise (and viscously, ignorantly degrade - you know who
you are, those whose reviews appear under the "hated" tag on the
reviews pages) and criticize the movie. I can't add anything that
hasn't been said before, except just say how much this movie affected
me and how much I love it. Tim Robbins, always a great actor, and always very, very human. Morgan
Freeman, c'mon, who da man? Who da MAN?!?!? HE DA MAN!!! He DA MAN!!!
He DA smooth-walkin', smoother-talking', illest muthaf***in' epitome of
"cool". And not a bad actor, either, heh heh (yes, I know I am
drastically understating that fact). The direction - flawless. Every shot, every camera angle, every color
tone (plus the quality of the film and the cameras themselves) embody
such finesse, such power. Humanity! That's what the word I was looking
for, the word that describes what every frame overwhelmingly emanates,
even during the "brutal" scenes (I put "brutal" in quotes because I
unfortunately have seen plenty of sick s@%* in my life and am now sadly
desensitized to movie violence; violence on the news and in real life
though, DAMN I get sickened and angered at perpetrators). The very
human friendship twixt the leads are very well handled, never turning
into cutesy schmaltz or soap-y melodrama. The writing. Yes, I know. "How the hell does his cell open up into a
pipe drain? That's horrible plot!!!!!!" Ask yourselves: If his cell
wall didn't open up over the pipe, would he have escaped? Would the
story have been the same AT ALL if his cell opened up anywhere else
other than that river of s@%*? And then think about Andy. Would someone
of his intelligence would have discontinued his digging and succumbed
to madness if what he saw when he looked through the initial tiny hole
on the other side was anything other than a road to freedom? Convenient
plot twist? Sure! But not outlandish. It could happen (not like a New
York Cop winning a $4M lottery ticket and tipping a waitress half, no
matter how much he wanted to get with her). Very good storytelling and
very tight screen writing. This movie is great. Plain and simple. It did confirm one thing in
general to me, though, especially in these times of moral conflict that
is dividing the "greatest nation on the face of the earth" bitterly:
Those who thump the bible the hardest, usually cling to it the hardest
out of fear and out of guilt. Love this film.

above a must watch movie.

******
13 May 2005
10
When Portland banker Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins) is unjustly convicted
of murder and sent to prison, he quickly learns that life on the inside
is harsh and unforgiving. Thankfully, he also forges a powerful
friendship with Red (Morgan Freeman) a fellow lifer who learns to
appreciate Andy's spirit and determination. Later, when Andy set's
himself up as the resident financial adviser to the warden and guards,
he manages to earn an odd form of respect from all he comes in contact
with. Based on the Stephen King novella "Rita Hayworth and the
Shawshank Redemption", it is story about friendship, hope and the
triumph of the human spirit over incredible hardship. Hows that for a clich√©d synopsis? This may summarize what the film is
about, but it does not explain why this film resonates so much with
audiences worldwide. Now, I remember the first time I read this short story by Stephen King.
I opened up "Different Seasons" because I wanted to read "The Body",
the novella which is the basis for "Stand By Me". After I had finished
that one I saw this oddly titled story at the beginning of the
anthology. I started reading it and did not stop till later that day,
when, with tears in my eyes, I put the book down. My first thought was
"that was a great story!" and I was amazed that King could write
something so inspirational. Then I thought to myself "that would make a
great picture".A year or so later - this film was released, and I went to the theater
with high hopes. The memories of this story were still cemented in my
imagination (I had actually pictured William Sadler as Red when I read
the book) and I was not disappointed by what I saw. In fact, If
anything I was even more impressed with the film because Darabont
managed to capture the nuance and feel of the original story so
perfectly. The look and feel of the prison and the characterizations of
Red and Andy where inspired. Nobody carries the regal dignity and
wisdom of Red like Morgan Freeman, and Tim Robbins was perfectly
enigmatic as Dufresne. Add to that Thomas Newmans stoic and moving
score, and what I saw was nothing short of movie magic. I walked out of
the theater, my heart soaring and knowing I had just watched a great
picture. I have only felt that way a few times before or since ("Field
of Dreams" and "Dances With Wolves" are two good examples) and I still
get that feeling when I watch it at home.This is more than a prison escape movie - it is, to me, a film about
the friendship between Red and Andy. I think so many men are fans of
this picture because Andy and Red have a connection that we would all
like to have with our friends, and that only a few of us are fortunate
enough to share or experience. I went to a marriage retreat recently,
and when the men and women were split up and asked to describe their
likes and dislikes, the question of movies came up. I think it is
interesting to note that all of us men listed this film as one of our
top ten.King has a way of writing language that is both common and lyrical at
the same time, and his characters have a wisdom and moral certainty
that connects with the reader. Kings skill as a writer is especially
evident in this picture with Freemans' narration. A lot of the lines
which he spoke are direct from the book, and this is a testament to
Darabont's respect for that written word. The screenplay he wrote was
more than just a faithful adaptation - it is an homage to the wonderful
story King wrote.I have read a lot of reviews and comments on this site that refer to
this film as "over-hyped" and "cliched", and to some extent this may be
true. This movie doesn't have a plot thats overly complicated, and the
characters (specifically the warden and prison guards) may be slightly
two-dimensional - but I think that was done on purpose. I believe
Stephen King wrote this story as an example of how a simple concept
like "hope" can pull someone through a very difficult time - and it is
this idea that appeals to so many people. This movie doesn't make any
social commentary, and it is certainly not PC - which is refreshing.
Too many films today are nothing more than political soapboxes for the
film-maker, and unfortunately the cynics and idealists prefer that sort
of commentary to simple story-telling. It has been said by fans of this movie, that "It's a Wonderful Life"
was pooh-poohed by critics when it was released as sentimental tripe -
and if the same film had been made today, it would be similarly scoffed
and mocked with abandon for it's old-fashioned sensibilities. Now,
people look at it as a classic, and rightly so, because it has a simple
message that people love to hear, over and over. That's what "The
Shawshank Redemption" is like. It's just a great story about friendship
that is told well, and most people appreciate that and that is why its
one of the top ten films on this website."Get busy living, or get busy dying."

******
11 May 2005
10
Andy is a wealth banker with a beautiful wife and big house. Everyone
would think he has everything in the world. That is till he finds out
that his wife has cheated on him. He turns to drinking and becomes
violent, but could this shy, handsome banker be capable of the
unthinkable. After the vicious murder of his wife and lover, he is
sentenced to life imprisonment at Shawshank Prison where he is bashed,
tormented and even gang raped. But nothing can dampen his spirit that
he will be free one day. A few years into the sentence, he becomes well
respected, no just among the criminals also inside, but to the prison
officers. There is a twist in the end,that will have you on the edge of
your seat. Can you pick it?

the latter.Tim Robbins and Freeman makes some powerful acting which is top notch,

colorful performances from all involved.The story is really a masterpiece but to put it out so well in a movie
is even harder. And the twists are surprising but makes it even better.

you are given a glimpse of the though conditions there is always that
sense of upbeat aura in the characters and u can't help but smile on a
few occasions even though there might not be much to smile about. There
is so much u can say about this movie but I just say this, this is as
good as drama gets.

3 May 2005
10
"Andy Dufresne - who crawled through a river of s@#t and came out clean
on the other side." Fantastic story line. Tim Robbins and Morgan
Freeman are mesmerizing as "Andy Dufresne" and "Red" respectively. As
are "Warden Norton" and Clancy Brown("Capt. Hadley). Excellent
characterizations throughout the film make you feel what it's like to
be wrongly imprisoned and the sense of hopelessness. The director is
deft with the story twists and turns. Original and unique camera angles
give you a real feel for "being there"...in that oppressive Maine state
prison. The cinematography and the musical score are expansive and
lush. Countless great lines. "I find I'm so excited, I can barely sit still
or hold a thought in my head. I think it the excitement only a free man
can feel, a free man at the start of a long journey whose conclusion is
uncertain. I hope I can make it across the border. I hope to see my
friend, and shake his hand. I hope the Pacific is as blue as it has
been in my dreams. I hope." - Red "Geology is the study of pressure and time. Thats all it takes
really... pressure... and time... That, and a big god@#$n poster." "Fear can hold you prisoner. Hope can set you free." - Ad Poster for
this movie.A true original. I have seen these movie many times and it never gets
old. "Get busy living or get busy dying"...

To be fair, I also have to admit that I am a big fan of Stephen King
and the screenplay was so honest to the story so there's probably that
extra appreciation personally. I just read another review and I felt
obligated to agree! There really aren't words to describe this movie.
It gets better and better every time I see it and it doesn't matter
where I start. I have seen it at least five times every year since
2000. It has to be my all-time favorite, hands down. The movies are the
ultimate escapism for me and this movie does just that, yet it depicts
something that we know too well, being a victim of circumstance or a
witness of circumstances. Andy is the victim and Red is the witness,
connecting in a way where you had to be there to understand. Kudos too
to Stephen King for always knowing exactly how to capture our worst
fears and materializing it. Whether it's the harsh punishment for a
crime one did not commit or realizing that you've been so
"institutionalized" by the very walls you hated that you no longer know
how to live without it, this movie exudes a sense of hope much welcomed
to many.And though some of us may not absolutely believe in it, we are
nonetheless glad it's lingering just close enough for us to know it's
there. It's such a well done piece, please go see it.

24 April 2005
10
Starring: Tim Robbins, Morgan Freeman There are some movies that when
you watch them you can't help but feel you've done more than watch a
movie. Sometimes it feels like you've been part of something bigger,
like you witnessed a masterpiece. The Shawshank Redemption is like
watching poetry. It is one of the most tragic, heartfelt, and deeply
satisfying stories to have ever been put onto the big screen. There
really is a reason that this movie is number two on the internet movie
database's top movies of all time.The premise of the movie is fairly simple. Andy Dufraine (Robbins) is
wrongfully accused with the murder of his wife and her lover, and he is
sentenced to two life sentences to be served back to back at Shawshank
prison. The plot is simple, and yet at the same time deeply complex.
This movie is a celebration of the human spirit, a celebration of hope
and of freedom.Life is difficult for Andy right from the beginning of his life
sentence. It takes him at least a month before he goes and talks to
anyone. The first person he does talk to is Red (Freeman), a man in the
prison who is able to get things. Need to get a pack of cigarettes, a
toothbrush, maybe some playing cards, then Red is your man on the
inside. Andy asks Red to pick up a rock hammer so that he can carve
stones.This movie is anything but a fairy tale. It depicts prison life as
being cruel, unfair, bitter, and downright horrible. Decent people die,
people get gang raped, the guards beat the ever-loving daylights out of
anyone who steps out of line. Shawshank prison is one hard place to
serve your time.After being in prison for a couple years, Andy gets transferred from
laundry duty to library, mainly so the warden can send his men over to
get financial advice from Andy. Andy starts doing income tax for the
guards and the warden, setting up trust funds, and various other
financial services, and after a few years, he becomes the man who
launders the warden's dirty money. Sure, he got transferred to the
library, but the only difference is he's washing money and not sheets
and clothes.Andy takes up all sorts of projects while he's in Shawshank. He makes
chess pieces for a chess board, he makes it his personal task to obtain
funds for and build a new prison library. He helps several of the
inmates get their high school equivalence. He does whatever he can to
pass the time and keep himself a little bit sane.I'd hate to spoil the ending for anybody who hasn't seen this movie, so
I will be very vague. All I will say is that it is one of the most
satisfying and beautiful endings to any movie or story that has ever
been captured. This movie is a masterpiece, and you would do yourself a
favour to make sure you watch it. And if you've already seen it, watch
it again, and introduce somebody else to the world of Shawshank prison.Bottom Line: 4 out of 4 (own this movie)

never received the recognition it mot truly deserves

sources, Stephen King. I have never been a fan of his horror work and
doubt I ever will be but his serious side has proved to be quite
excellent. Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins were robbed by the Academy

performances. Morgan Freeman that comes as no shock as he can elevate
most anything from trash to gold so when you give him a good role it
becomes practically transcendent.Tim Robins was more of a surprise to me. I have seen him in a few
movies but he never really left much of an impression on me. In this
film though he provided one of the 90's best performances. The rest of
the cast also filled out quite well. James Whitemore was heartbreaking
in his role as the elderly librarian. This movie deserves its spot on
at #2 on the IMDb top list and I would actually argue that it should
bump The Godfather out as I think that movie is highly over-rated but
then that's just me.If you haven't seen this movie than I suggest that you go out and rent
it now. Better yet just buy it as I doubt you will be disappointed.
Cheers!

20 March 2005
10
(Spoilers)The Shawshank Redemption. A large Maine penitentiary where one
convicted banker/murder ends up. Andy Dufrey (Tim Robbins) has landed a
double life sentence in the penitentiary and must deal with life behind
bars. During the duration of this powerhouse of a movie we see how
inmates are truly institutionalized and their lives are virtually
destroyed by their time spent in jail.After the suicide of Brooks, the movie takes a new turn and Andy's
character begins to develop. He remodels the jail library, helps guards
with their taxes and even finds the time to educate inmates. But during
these times the Warden begins to bet Andy involved with illegal
activity. Not to ruin it I'll leave it at that. The Shawshank Redemption is the definition of an amazing movie. While
being entertaining and emotional the movie shows us the atrocities of
jail life that only Stephen King could bring and how even in the
darkest of times hope can survive. Robbins as Dufrey and Freeman as his
buddy Red both do amazing jobs with their characters and deserved more
than it was awarded by the Academy and Golden Globes. The Shawshank Redemption. 5 out of 5 Stars.

financial work for one of the warders, and all the prisoners get beer
as a result. He just sits back and smiles - and his unselfish act has
such excellent consequences for him, both with his relations with the
other prisoners, the 'sisters' and the guards.

brilliant. This is one case where the movie is actually far better than
the book or short story.

ever to win the best picture", it broke my heart with the same impact
that the year 1994 did when it released Shawshank and Forrest in the
same year. I went to the movies 3 times to see Forrest Gump during the
summer after I graduated High School. I couldn't have identified with a
movie any more during this phase of limbo and floating through life
both laughing and crying. Unfortunately, I was so enraptured with this
film and my innocence of being 18 that I did not see Shawshank until it
was released on video and I viewed this movie 3 times with 3 different
groups of people in 24 hours, running around my South Jersey area
looking for worthy disciples that had also missed out on one of the
best movies I had ever seen as well. Shawshank was a victim of
circumstance not only in my little world but in the real world as well.
I wish it could have somehow won a co-Acadamy Award, like a rare-MVP
award in sports, but it would take away from its infamous underdog/goat
status like the Boston Red Sox. (who knows maybe they will wait 86
years and finally give it the praise it is due?)

adaptation of "The Shinig" and Darbonts "The Green Mile". frank

get bored, you may think that there is not much that goes on in this
movie but there is always something that is happening. At the beginning you think that Andy(Robbins) will not be able to last
the first night, and you see Red(Freeman) and his friends making bets
on who will freak out, to their surprise it is the fatty who freaks and
Hadley beats him over the head which ends up killing him. After this
Andy knows he is going to have to stand up for himself, he quickly
becomes friends with Red but enemies with Heywood. Heywood and his
friends would beat on Andy because he is the new guy. I wont say
anything else about the movie because I don't want to give any
spoilers. 10/10

10
When I first came across the title "Shawshank Redemption" I didn't have
a clue as to what it was about, since I didn't know the plot. But it
had Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman as it's stars, so I figured that it
was worth a peek. What a peek!! This movie is awesome!! Not the classic
tale of a innocent man being sent to jail for a crime that he didn't
commit, this movie was much more detailed. It shows you how cruel
prison life can be. (Although, if you want a better picture of prison
life today, I suggest watching "American Me") You have everything in
this picture, Corrupt Prison Warden, Sadistic Guards, and a innocent
man caught in the middle. You can not help but admire Tim Robbins
character "Andy Dufresne" as he waits patiently for almost 20 years
before he is able to rectify his situation. Talk about patience and
perseverance! This is one movie that will tug at your heart. Excellent
movie.

10
This is simply one of the greatest if not "the greatest" movie ever
made. It's a beautiful story, presented excellently by Frank Darabont,
and brilliant writing in the part of Stephen King.Even though this is a fictional story, it's so well presented, that you
feel like you're a silent character in the film. You are made to feel
like your're in the cast. You almost expect your name to appear in the
credits. The character development was excellent, from the main
characters played by Morgan Freeman, and Tim Robbins, all the way to
"the sisters", Although we may not have liked them, we feel that we
somehow know them and can relate to their specific plights. However it
was done very well, because none of them overshadow the main
characters, and the main plot of the film. Undoubtedly a Classic.
Should be studied as long as film exists.

14 January 2005
8
The Shawshank Redemption is considered by many to be one of the
greatest films of all time. Yet as with any classic, we must not be
blinded by its popularity, lest we overlook its flaws. And The
Shawshank Redemption is not without its difficulties, but beyond those
difficulties lies a heartfelt film, a film resilient in its
hopefulness.The Shawshank Redemption, for the most part, is seen through the eyes
of Red, a prisoner in a high-security Maine prison who has been
convicted on a charge of murder. Yet Red is not the true focus of the
film, as Andy Dufresne steps onto the scene, convicted of murdering his
wife and her lover. Red soon develops a friendship with Dufresne, and
Red observes Dufresne like a curious onlooker, awed by his courage and
knowledge.These characters, the compelling story, and the direction are the three
strongest points of the film. Each character is filled with life and
plays an important role in both the film as a whole and in Dufresne's
life. Never for a moment does the viewer question the plausibility of
the characters and the circumstances in which they find themselves.
This is where the story comes in, as the film contrasts dark reality
with brilliance of hope. The story sucks the viewer into the film from
the beginning, until it is so captivating, that the viewer could not
escape if he tried. Furthermore, I was pleasantly amazed by Durabont's
direction, as he creatively used the camera to capture even more
wonderfully the hopefulness of the film.However, Durabont has other difficulties, amongst which is the
screenplay that he himself authored. Yes, there are times when the
screenplay is emotional and heart-breaking, but there are also some
foolish, implausible lines that detract from the movie's effect. Words
were sometimes spoken when there should have been silence, leaving less
interpretation up to the viewer while spitting clich√©s out from the
characters' mouth. I felt that the acting was lacking a bit as well,
even though as the viewer gets more used to the characters, their
acting seems to fit, albeit imperfectly.In conclusion, the high points of this film are higher than the low
points are low. People generally like this film, and it's easy to see
why, as it examines human existence in its own distinctive way. This
examination has led it be considered one of the best films of the
1990s.Final Grade: A-.

******
10 January 2005
10
The Shawshank Redemption is my favourite movie of all time. Why? Well
as you can see it is third now in the list of IMDb.com top movies ever
and is praised by actually everyone i've talked about it and every
critic. But that's not me. Everyone can have their say and mine is that
big part of this movies high quality comes from the everlasting theme
of hope and of the fact that the filmmakers can make you like and even
love the characters, though they are murderers, thieves and so on. That
is hard to achieve and it is a remarkable mistake not to have honored
the best adapted screenplay Oscar to this movie. Best picture also
would have been the right choice(though it would have been fun to see
Pulp Fiction win). And of course not only the movie's acting is perfect
everything else is in it's superb place too. The music, the
cinematography etc.What happens is that, to ME, this movie is perfect. It's got everything
a movie need and then some(and more). Maybe you can say it's caused bit
of the hype of everyone saying it is such great movie, but I can't deny
it's place on example in this list, and nor can I say that it is
overrated. So if you haven't seen it(and you propably have) the watch
it as soon as you can! You just must...

7 January 2005
10
I didn't see this movie in the theaters when it came out. I had never
been a big Steven King fan, and it just didn't catch my imagination. A
friend brought the video over one night for us to watch it, and MAN! I
was blown away. The theme of the movie is hope, and what hope, and the
lack thereof, does to people. This is truly one of the most uplifting
films which I think was ever made.I thought that everything in the film clicked. The acting, the
direction, the cinematography, the music, all were perfect. I have read
some posts where people don't like the ending, but I think the
regressing shot of the two friends is right on; you see the culmination
of the struggle to be free for both men, yet it's not in your face
sappy.As far as the best scene, I would have to say it's a three way toss-up:1: The aria scene 2: Brook's suicide 3: Red in the wheat fieldI probably pull the DVD out once a month or so to watch this gem. JRW

******
5 January 2005
10
The Shawshank Redemption is about Andy Dufresne who was sent to
Shawshank Prison for the double homicide of his cheating wife and her
secret lover. But instead of feeling sorry for himself he lived the
best he could and bettered the lives of fellow inmates through shear
determination. In the process, he made many friends (Ellis 'Red'
Redding being most notable of all) and even gained the respect of
prison guards. Despite of serving back to back life sentences, Andy
never gave up his ultimate dream of one day living by the ocean. That
dream was further jeopardized because of what he knew, and there was
someone who will go to great lengths to keep him locked up forever.
Will Andy finally crack and lose hope, or will his perseverance
prevail?The Shawshank Redemption is the best movie that I've ever seen. I even
like it better than any of the Godfather movies (which have a
completely different theme up to the last episode). Perhaps I like this
movie so much because it suits my taste. But I think most viewers of
all kinds will appreciate Shawshank for the superb acting of the main
characters, the insightful dialogs throughout, the powerful message it
conveys, and the realness of the lives of convicts both inside the
prison and outside once they're paroled.It's a shame that Shawshank didn't win many awards since '94 was a
tremendous year with the release of other great films like Pulp Fiction
and Forrest Gump. But the acting and directing of this film was still
outstanding. I can't ever imagine serving a life sentence, and prison
life was much different in the mid 1900's from today. Still I was able
to relate to what the main characters were feeling, and I was moved by
their words and actions numerous times (especially those of Brooks).The underlying theme of Shawshank was simple; it celebrated hope and
perseverance just like Lord of the Rings. Hope and perseverance are
indeed powerful elements in arts, and both films have done a marvelous
job portraying these two aspects. However, Shawshank seemed more real
because frankly it was set in our world and not a fantasy one. This is
no knock against LOTR, but I find myself more involved in this film
because I could relate to it more and it made a deeper impact on me.******POSSIBLE SPOILERS BELOW******Of course no film is perfect. There are minor details here and there
than didn't make sense to me. For example, how could the wall fall
apart so easily? How could Andy cut/break such a big hole through that
steel pipe with a rock? How can Shawshank Prison ignore the smuggling
of things (they definitely knew since there were posters on the prison
walls and men were smoking smuggled cigarettes)? But these are minor
things, and don't jeopardize the integrity of Shawshank.I don't want to over-analyze Shawshank and give it away, but I would
highly recommend it to anyone who's in the mood for a serious film. My
final rating: 10/10.

give you so much hope and happiness. It really is that brilliant. In
fact i'm watching it now.WATCH IT NOW 10/10- Probably the greatest movie ever made

rated 10!

5 December 2004
10
Frank Darabont's "The Shawshank Redemption", starring Tim Robbins and
Morgan Freeman, is the greatest film ever made in Hollywood. Plain and
simple. The film tells the involving story of two prisoners at
Shawshank Prison, and their decades together under the thumb of a cruel
warden and his henchman. Andy (Tim Robbins, never better) is an
innocent man, who uses his accounting skills to make himself useful to
the warden, and struggles to keep up hope, against the counsel of his
fellow inmates. Red (Morgan Freeman, astonishing) thinks hope is a
dangerous thing, and is an institutionalized man, who can't imagine
life outside of the prison walls. The film also stars Bob Gunton,
Clancy Brown, William Sadler, and, in a powerful performance, James
Whitmore. I'll say no more, because this film must be seen to be
understood.

19 October 2004
10
This is by far one of the best movies made. It talks of hope, patience,
the will to prove the truth and above all, friendship. Andy's fight
with hopelessness and the tragedy that he is forced to face is truly
inspiring. Not once do we see him beaten down by the situation. He not
only saves himself but also puts back new life into the likes of Red
and Tommy. A few scenes like the time when Andy plays the music over
the loudspeaker, "Brooks was here, So was Red", the climax are all
unforgettable. The dialogues and the performances are flawless. Andy is wrongly accused of killing his wife and her lover. He ends up
in Shawshank, a place where a normal being would succumb to the
helplessness. But Andy fights it out. The "change" Andy brings about in
the situation in Shawshank is probably impossible. The story is
narrated by Red, Andy's best friend inside and later. Truly, an amazing
movie!

******
18 October 2004
9
Hope. It is the single most powerful human emotion. It can keep you
alive, and it can destroy your life. Hope can be the one thing left in
a world where everything else is taken from you- and The Shawshank
Redemption is the perfect artistic visualization of the tremendous
power that hope can have over someone who has lost everything else. The opening scene introduces us to a young and successful banker named
Andy Dufresne, and the things that have transpired to destroy his life.
We can't help but feel sympathy toward a man who finds out that his
wife is having an affair, and then gets convicted for the double
homicide of his wife and her lover- when he is innocent of the crime.
Taken to Shawshank prison for two life sentences, Andy has had his
entire life taken from him in a spiral of terrible events. It only gets
worse at the prison, as the brutality of the prison guards is
unbridled, and a few inmates make his life hell. However, Andy
continually surprises the audience with his resilience and his
character finds ways to amaze the inmates, the guards, the warden, and
the audience. The story itself is not wholly original or
groundbreaking, and there is no 'surprise-ending' or major twists that
come out of nowhere to shock the audience. However, it is in the
delivery of the story that this film excels beyond all others. Every aspect of this movie compliments the incredible script written by
Frank Darabont that was based on Stephen King's novella. The music is a
composition of slow-moving and peaceful ballads that bring out just how
long-winded a life sentence in prison can be, and how undaunted Andy is
by the terrible environment he is in. The cameras move slowly and
steadily, repeatedly scanning the prison and also emphasizing the
endless span that life in prison truly is. On the artistic side, the
movie is something to behold. But ultimately, what brings the entire
movie together is the beautifully written and exceptionally delivered
narration of Morgan Freeman, playing a fellow inmate named Ellis 'Red'
Redding. Not only are we given a view into Andy's character through
this man's observations, but we also see how Red himself changes his
life as a result of Andy Dufresne.The amazing thing about this film is how every detail in the entire
movie somehow contributes to the story on the whole. It takes a few
times of viewing before you can really appreciate just how intricate
the plot is- how every single moment helps increase the power of the
incredible ending sequence. It is not too complex, with many tangents
that end up confusing the viewer. Instead, it runs with a simple theme
and adds to it with everything that is depicted. The only negative
thing I have to say about this movie is that the ending seems a bit
drawn out, but by this time you are so enthralled and satisfied as a
viewer that it should not pose a problem. A great story, told flawlessly, with a powerful message. There is not a
lot more that you could ask for in a movie. Entertaining and inspiring.
Deep, yet not complicated. A message delivered with undeniable power,
and an excellent movie experience overall. If you have ever felt like
everything has been taken from you, then learn from Andy Dufresne.
'There's something inside that they can't get to, that they can't
touch. It's yours.' Hope. It can set you free.

******
17 October 2004
10
I am a movie buff, seen just about all the classics, new and old, but
Shawshank is number 1. I think LOR attempts, in a much more complicated
manner, to deliver a similar theme - hope even in the most bleak of
times. Shawshank delivers this message even more effectively than LOR,
and crystalizes the message of hope as the single most important thing
in our lives, even more than love. Many of us do not have love in our
lives - but hope makes us continue, search for a better life, a better
day. I like to put it this way, nothing ever good in this world ever
came from quitting, giving up. All that is good in this world, came
through persistance, hard work, determination.....hope. No other piece
of movie making has ever reflected this message better than The
Shawshank Redemption.

10
I picked this up on video seven years ago. The movie bombed in the UK.
The story inspires hope, whether your male or female. The rich
characterization is skillfully handled by Robbins and Freeman.
Darabont's script sets up quite a gripping visual antagonism that
wholly rewards the audience with a feel-good ending. It made me weep,
time and again. And when you lose hope the film's portrayal of
redemption over adversity can lead to your own redemption. The power of
the visual and the word of hope make this a great film. It has already
spurned the box office in favour of the people. It is more than just a
commercial venture it is a damn good yarn that provides inspiration to
those who need it. It is the William Blake of scripture, dividing
heaven and hell, and the corruption of good. My video copy wore out
earlier this year so I'm happily in possession of the 10th anniversary
DVD. Best movie in 75 years. Buy two copies your sure to get one
stolen.

6 October 2004
10

The Shawshank Redemption is easily the greatest movie ever. It is such
an amazing journey of two people throughout approximately twenty years
of a prison sentence. The evolution of their friendship (Andy played by
Tim Robbins and Red played by Morgan Freeman) over that period is just
amazing how they go from not knowing each other to very close best
friends. I love to see how Andy, through his financial prowess, is able
to accomplish so much for him, his friends, and fellow prisoners. Bob
Gunton as the warden and Clancy Brown as the head prison guard were
also amazing in there roles. Brown was very authoritative and violent
in his control of the prison. Gunton was impressive as the corrupt
warden who did not like to be reminded of his misdeeds. I love when he
goes nuts when Andy asks how he can be so obtuse. I think that is
hilarious how somebody would take as much offense to the word obtuse.
The way that the movie ends is what made this my favorite movie of all
time. I did not see that ending coming at all and I will not spoil it.
To explain how great this movie is I would say this: If you have seen
the movie Gymkata and know how extremely bad that movie (except that
its badness makes it hilarious), The Shawshank Redemption is as great
as Gymkata is bad. This has been my review of the greatest movie ever
and everybody should see this movie at least once.

28 September 2004
8

The criteria for a classic film to become timeless is very simple. It
must speak to every generation that comes in contact with it. Films
like the The Wizard of Oz and Gone With the Wind, both which were
released in 1939, have obviously aged well. The Wizard of Oz, like The
Shawshank Redemption, was not an immediate success and yet it grew an
audience. The Shawshank Redemption is a well told story that seems to
connect with people on a basic level. It has also subsequently grown in
viewership in its first decade. It will be very interesting to see how
it fares 50 years from now. Will this film stand the test of time? Will
this film always remain a favorite among audiences?

entertaining enough, so I charitably gave it an 8 and I think that's
fair. Is this movie the second best of all time? NOT! I think 53% of

the end, sure it was neat but check your warm n' fuzzies folks. Other
movies that are overrated at IMDb because of a neat twist at the end are
The Usual Suspects and The Sixth Sense. A twist does not make it
Perfect.

9 September 2004
10

The Shawshank Redemption fills me with joy and hope every time I watch
it, which must be well over a few dozen times now. Tim Robbins' acting
is excellent as the emotionally repressed banker in jail but Morgan
Freeman, who is consistently superb in all his roles, carries the
weight of this movie's intelligently uplifting spirit, its pathos,
warmth and humanity. Freeman narrates the story and it's his rich voice
that details the life in jail and with his majestic, patient compassion
adds color to what otherwise might have felt abjectly bleak. Whenever I
feel down I watch this movie for inspiration. This is the sort of movie
I think people of all ages can enjoy, many times over, seeing it with
new eyes at different times in their lives.


******
8 September 2004
10

"The Shawshank Redemption" is a film practically void of flaw: a
monumental, impeccable gem, succeeding marvelously as a heartfelt tale
of hardship, friendship, and above all, redemption. Practically every
element in this film is either extremely satisfying or undeniably
excellent, as everything one might desire in a dramatic experience, and
even a film experience, is executed with perfect conviction, from the
brilliant, compelling performance of Morgan Freeman, to the passionate,
relentless direction, to the enchanting, whimsical screenplay, to the
powerful, befitting score; this film succeeds on nearly every level. It
is entertainment at its best, featuring an amusing, rousing story of
survival and redemption, while attaining those sincere, practical, and
original qualities a "film purist" will heartily enjoy. You follow
Morgan Freeman and Tim Robbins through their every experience, as their
trials, tribulations, and redemption are the central themes of the
story. You develop an intense bond with their struggles, and how they
manage to overcome so many hardships and injustices, while still
retaining confidence and hope. The resounding message here is "Fear can
hold you prisoner, Hope can set you free", and oh, what a powerful,
important message for all of us to consider. It is an absolute travesty
that this brilliant, enchanting, and impeccable film was rejected for
even a single Oscar. Any other year than Forrest Gump and this would
have won gold; such a shame. I loved practically everything about this
film, as an entertainment, as an artistic achievement, and as a lesson
of life: "Get busy living, or get busy dying." What a wonderful film
"Shawshank" is. **** out of ****


******
7 September 2004
10

This is one of my all time favorites! With Tim Robbins and Morgan
Freeman, you cannot go wrong! It's like everything is just perfect.I really appreciated every moment of this piece of art! If you're into
prison movies, well this is for sure the best around!Every fan of Morgan Freeman should get this one, it's probably his best

it.Buy this one, it's really worth the money!This one gets,an easy 10!


******
3 September 2004
10

Currently, on the IMDb top 250 Movies of All Time list, the top two
movies both hold ratings of 9.0. Of these two, "The Shawshank
Redemption" has roughly twenty thousand more votes in its favor. Ergo,
I do believe that "The Shawshank Redemption" should finally ascend to
its rightful place on this web-page, and hopefully cinema history, as
the Greatest Film of All Time. That having been said, I wish now to give my own thoughts on this film,
thoughts which will be hitherto corrupted by myriad spoilers.The acting is astounding. Tim Robbins as Andy Dufresne delivers the
perfect combination of hope and despair, so that you can love his
character without ever truly knowing what he shall do next. Morgan
Freeman brings subtlety and depth to a character who would perhaps
otherwise be much simpler. Bob Gunton allows you to genuinely fear
Warden Norton, and if James Whitmore's performance does not make you
lachrymose, nothing can.The plot is beautiful, describing the redemption of many an inmate.
Red, though he does not escape institutionalization, becomes a good
man. Tommy Williams does the same. The best of all endings however, is
Andy's, as he goes through so much to come out clean in the end,
something expressed both allegorically throughout the story and
literally at the end.The greatest film I have ever seen.


******
28 August 2004
9

'I wish that I could tell you that Andy fought the good fight¬Öand the
Sisters let him be. I wish I could tell you that¬Öbut prison is no
fairy-tale world.' This quote nicely sums up The Shawshank Redemption,
a film that earnestly shows the violent life in prison, but chooses not
to focus on the violence, rather using it to portray emotion.Andy Dufresne (Tim Robbins), a successful banker, is convicted for the
murder of his wife and her lover. The judge describes Andy as cold and
sends him to the Shawshank prison to serve two life sentences. Andy,
however, maintains his innocence, despite the fact that he was seen at
the murder scene carrying a weapon.In prison, Andy eventually gains the respect of his inmates, including
the influential prisoner 'Red' (Morgan Freeman) who 'gets things' for
the prisoners. Later, Andy's knowledge of finance gains him popularity
with the cruel prison guards and the Warden (Bob Gunton).The development of the friendship between Red and Andy is one of the
focal points of the film as each man learns from the other. Several
subplots are nicely intertwined into the film, none better than the
story of old Brooks Hatlen (James Whitmore) and his release from
prison. Having spent so much time at Shawshank, Brooks has become
'institutionalised' i.e. so attached to prison that he cannot cope in
the outside world. The sense of helplessness and solitude Brooks feels
when released is one of the films most genuinely emotional moments.The plot of the movie is solid, and while it encompasses some 20 years,
it transitions well and never really feels slow. Credit for this must
go to screenwriter Frank Darabont who nicely adapts Stephen King's
novel to the big screen. The entire cast of the movie gives standout performances, led by
Robbins. Robbins portrays Andy beautifully throughout the film,
especially with his facial expressions. His eyes are incredibly focused
and haunting throughout and he often wears a smile on his face that
belies his situation. Freeman does well as Red, playing him with
confidence and a sense of despair at the same time.Visually the film opts for a very grey tone that fits in with the
dreary feel of the prison and the prisoners. It also succeeds in
helping Andy to stick out, as his hope and demeanour contradict the
tone.The Shawshank Redemption is a truly beautiful film, easily one of the
best of the 90's, filled with a great story, acting, emotion and a
series of memorable quotes.


******
27 August 2004
10

There are some movies that come along that truly make a difference in
cinema and in peoples lives. In my opinion, this is one of those films.***spoilers*** (minor)The movie is about a man wrongfully accused of a crime. He is sentenced
to life in prison. He ends up at Shawshank. A prison with a lot more
going on than what shows on the outside.There are quite a few things that make this film a masterpiece. One is
the story and its qualities and values. Another is its amazing acting
by all cast members in the film. The music was great and the
cinematography is creative. I don't believe there's a flaw in this
movie.11/10 haha!

25 August 2004
8
Superb acting and brilliant performances from Tim Robbins (Mystic
River) and Morgan Freeman (Million Dollar Baby), who play as inmates,
Tim Robbins playing a man framed for the murder of his wife and the man
who she had an affair with. The two inmates develop a friendship over
the twenty odd years spent in the prison.This movie portrays an ugly, though bearable life in prison through the
40s, 50s, and 60s.It's a strong piece on how far one will go to redeem himself, even if
those things that must be redeemed are not by any means loathsome. See
it if you haven't.

24 August 2004
10

Morgan Freeman as Red was truly inspired (even if the original story had a
white guy), they even used his son for the photo of the inmate as a young
man...Tim Robbins as Andy DuFresne was marvelous understatement, Clancy brown as
the on/off guard-friend of Andy was a good touch and a boost for his career
apart from Starship Trooper... Now, Clancy is in HBO's "Carnivale" series
and has his own website! As for the warden and "sisters,"  they were equally
well-cast and the plot of the movie flowed despite what fan-sites may or may
not nit-pick about.It is a tribute to perseverance and determination combined with patience and
retribution couched in careful long-term planning that any true financial
head is accustomed to (remember, Andy was a Bank Manager, that knowledge
saved him more than once)...Justice sometimes comes from beyond the law if you can wait long enough!
This picture is second after "Casablanca"!!

******
9 August 2004
10

I find it amazing that a film like this rates so highly on the IMDb Top
250.It's not really a 'cinematic' film like LOTR or Star Wars- you don't
look at it and go 'wow, what an amazing shot!' or 'how did they do
that?'. Similarly, it's not chock-full of catch-phrases and snappy
dialogue like 'Pulp Fiction', 'Casablanca', or indeed memorable scenes
like 'the Godfather'. Could anyone really talk about 'Shawshank' in the
way that people always discuss 'the Godfather' or 'LOTR'- "remember
that moment when..."'Shawshank' isn't a big, spectacular film, and nor is it particularly
witty.Instead, its success is entirely down to the quality of the story,
helped along by some very 'real' acting. I've now seen this film 4-5
times on odd occasions, and it just gets better every time. The story
just draws you in- you feel for the characters, and I love the way the
surprise (well, surprise-ish) ending is perfectly believable without
ever being overtly signposted. I've heard that it's been much more
successful on DVD and video than it was at the cinema- and I think that
illustrates the type of movie it is.'Shawshank' is perhaps the best 'story' movie of recent times, and
clearly deserves its place near the top of the IMDb rankings. Watch it
curled up on the couch with a cup of coffee and a warm cosy wife...


******
7 August 2004
9
Overall, this is one of the finest films I've ever seen. Frank
Darabont's masterful screenplay rendering of Stephen King's marginal
novella brought every possible human emotion into play. And, every
actor in the film did a superb job of translating this fiction into a
believable reality.On a scale from 1 to 100, I'd rate this movie a solid 99. Only one
thing was lacking in the film to raise that score to 100 ... but this
is just a personal thing.POSSIBLE SPOILERS FOLLOWS:During his time in prison, Andy Dufresne learns the identity of the man
who killed his wife - a man named Elmo Blatch. And, he learns enough
information about Blatch to render him "trackable" by an investigator.
If 2 brief scenes had been added to the film, I'd have rated it a
perfect film:ADDED SCENE #1 - Shortly before his escape, Andy is seen talking to
another inmate who gives him contact info for a person on the outside
who does contract murder.ADDED SCENE #2 - Shortly before Red's release from prison, we see him
reading a newspaper story on the murder of an ex-con named Elmo Blatch.Between the time of Andy's escape and Red's release, there would have
been ample time for Andy to hire a private eye to track down Blatch
and, afterward, hire a contract killer to kill him. Had I been Andy,
I'd not have felt truly free of the suffering I'd endured in prison
unless I knew the real killer got his just due. What Andy did to the
Warden and Hadley is all well and good. But Blatch's death would settle
all scores once and for all.

A film I can watch over and over again - great storyline, beautifully
filmed, top-notch acting - I always feel good about myself after
watching it - there's hope for us all, even the most downtrodden
nonentities in this miserable world of ours! cinematic brilliance. Tim
Robbins plays the lead character's role with such a classy
understatement, & Morgan Freeman delivers a powerful and nuanced
performance that always lifts my soul as well as the great performance
by all the supporting actors. I will be the first person to admit to
having a slight eclectic taste in films, but this still ranks as one of
my favourite films of all time. This truly is my definition of
cinematic brilliance - pity we don't get more films like this anymore.

The finest movie ever made, no question. If you can sit through this
and not be moved by the sheer power of the story, performances and
imagery you are not of this earth. I had already read the Stephen King
short story so the ending was no surprise but, guess what, it didn't

so strong that all the other parts must have dropped into place with
,seemingly, effortless ease. Hopefully one day something better will
come along that will shift the goal posts once again. But for now, The
Shawshank Redemption is a more than worthy No. 1 on IMDb.

25 June 2004
10

This is a love story, as old as the hills and yet with freshness that
can only be given to us by great Celluloid actors such as Morgan
Freeman and Tim Robbins. There are many examples of this throughout
literature and the adaptation of this from word to film is
breathtaking.Andy and Red quite obviously have a deep and abiding love and respect
for each other that transcends any feeling we might otherwise have
about the nature of their love, which incidentally is not a homosexual
love.But let us not forget the other performances. How wonderful to see
James Whitmore as Brooks Hatlen and of course the brilliant William
Saddler. It would have been too easy to slip into a prison melodrama
but I think it was played perfectly by having Red narrate throughout,
the two most wonderful pieces of narrative are where Andy plays Mozart
over the prison loudspeakers and where Red sits in his cell, fearful
and alone in the dark on the night of Andy's escape. 'Some things are just too beautiful.' 'Time draws out like a blade.'I guess that encapsulates the whole thing for me, because it's how time
draws out while watching this beautiful picture. The blade cuts you to
the heart because you long for Red and Andy to fulfil their hope.If I could, I would give this more than 10 out of 10 but I cannot.
Instead I'll just say that this movie will give pleasure to people when
played as an oldie in 50 years, because the story is timeless. No
special effects, no fancy graphics, just a simple story, beautifully
told and acted superbly.


******
15 June 2004
10

I first saw this movie when Channel 4 showed it in the UK in September
2001. I had just come back from a wonderful holiday in Ohio, USA and
had never heard of this movie before. I just happened to flick to
channel 4 and caught a glimpse of Morgan Freeman watching Tim Robbins
make his entrance into Shawshank. I had missed the opening scene with
the court case. My first impressions was that this was going to be a
typical prison drama but I reached for the TV guide and read more about
it. It starred Morgan Freeman who I remember from Along Came a Spider
and Deep Impact and Tim Robbins who I have heard of but never seen on
screen before. The TV guide gave it a good rating and review so I
thought i might continue to watch it.In the opening scenes, I predicted possible rivalries between Andy and
Heywood, however I was glad this was not the case as both characters
became well-liked throughout the film. I even thought there would be
tension between Andy and Red, but I was delighted that they became best
friends throughout the movie. Along the way, I found the movie becoming
interesting with many plots running alongside each other and beautiful
photography. I held my breath when Hadley almost threw Andy off the
roof and Morgan Freeman's story telling was first rate. Another scene that moved me was Andy playing the Mozart record and
giving hope to all prisoners in Shawshank. I even went out to buy the
fantastic soundtrack with the song as well as the superb score by
Thomas Newman. I must say I was concerned when Andy got in trouble for
that stunt, as I thought eventually the warden was going to help him
solve his case. All the characters gave memorable performances and I
was moved by Brooks taking his own life as he couldn't cope on the
outside. I was shocked when Tommy revealed Andy's innocence and equally
curious when the warden refused to help him. Nothing prepared me for
the way Andy escaped, I was so glad he did but felt for Red at the same
time. I was thrilled when Red got his parole and just hoped he didn't feel
institutionalised like Brookes. I thought Red blew it when he talked up
to the parole board but had a chuckle when he finally left Shawshank.
Other moving scenes were Red reading Andy's letter and making his way
through the fields surrounded with grasshoppers. The scene that took my
breath away the most, was the shot of the bus as it made its way along
the road with the brilliant sunlight, it looked just like the area
where I had just come from in Ohio, as well as Red and Brookes in Main
Street, Mansfield which I recognised. This film is long, but it
certainly didn't seem that way to me, it is a movie you wish would go
on for a bit more longer. I was stunned at the end, very moved, very
happy and almost in tears. This film is truly a work of art, probably
the finest movie ever made with superb acting from all of the
characters, beautiful music, cinematography and so much better than the
novel it is based on. I cannot believe it did not win any Oscars
despite many nominations. It gives the viewer a sense of hope,
happiness and satisfaction all in one and anyone can see this movie
whatever mood they are in. The movie is also funny, who can forget
Hadley with his, "if I hear anything more than a mousefart..." or Tommy
explaining when he got arrested and had to drop a TV set. This movie
makes you feel great to be alive and as Red says this movie is "so
beautiful it cannot be expressed in words". I bought the DVD for my
family to watch and their stunned silence at end confirmed my
suspicions that they loved this movie too.Shawshank Redemption is going to be re-released in the UK in September
and I would encourage anyone who hasn't seen it before to go and see it
and hopefully feel the same way I felt when I first saw this movie.
There is so much to appreciate about this movie and everytime I see it
again, I love it even more.

10 June 2004
10

A wonderfully made movie. The best thing about movie is it never looses
its pace. Neither it gets fast nor it gets slow... Rightly placed at #2
on IMDb.Tim Robbins and Morgan Freeman makes a great pair in the movie.
Villain, Bob Gluton, the Jailer performs his role very well. "Hope is
good thing, probably one of the best thing, and no good thing ever
dies" is the central theme of the movie according to me. Calm, Placid banker Andrew Dufresene lives his life with hope without
loosing his temper. and that's the movie is all about. Frank Darabont
did an amazing job adapting from Stephen King's short story, and he
deserves as much praise for it as possible. Nobody, not even my
favourite writers such as the Coen brothers of Quentin Tarantino
(partly for the fact that the first only writes comedies and the latter
only fares in blood spatter) could have achieved this amazing script,
which completely uplifts and spellbinds the viewer.

29 May 2004
10

When viewers see a young banker's character (Dufresne) convicted of a
gruesome murder, and later when they see him vindicate himself with the
help of pure courage and hope, it evokes high emotions like triumph and
hope. Each scene is skillfully written with viewers' perspective
considered all through the film. Excellent work due to which Frank
Darabont never need prove himself as a director again, because this one
goes down in the history books as one of the best dramas ever written.Dufresne's character does what's on his mind says and never shows
feelings of captivity while at Shawshank. The character is carved out
meticulously displaying traits like intelligence and a mind determined
to surviveMorgan Freeman ('Red') delivers a brilliant performance, deserving the
Academy Award that year which ultimately landed up with Tom Hanks
('Forrest Gump').

29 May 2004
10

Well what can I say about this modern day classic that hasn't been told
already. It seems that most of us who have been lucky enough to watch
this gem have been profoundly moved by this story. Not hearing anything
about the release of this film in '96, I rented this out without any
idea what to expect, other than it was a prison drama. Now I love
prison flicks and my favourites are Brubaker, Birdman of Alcatrez and
Stir Crazy, but after watching Shawshank Redemption I can say this is
one of the best films ever made, and one of the very few movies that
made me cry, and it takes a lot for me to shed a tear. I think the last
time I cried was at my grandpas funeral, but that was a different
emotion to the one I felt watching the Shawshank Redemption. The ending
was filled with a great deal of satisfaction and hope that you rarely
get in any film today. If you want to watch a film that has a story
that covers human survival, struggle, bonding and hope and want to be
uplifted than this is the one to watch.

contrary big budget films are often the worst...
